However, given their very specific geographical situation, these initiatives have not been enough to prevent the region and its inhabitants from becoming marginalised. The aim of this report is to approve the European Commission proposal to review and, if necessary, extend these initiatives to help the inhabitants of Kaliningrad to travel to Europe. I voted in favour of this report.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – The proposal seeks to make an exception to the regulation to allow the whole of the Kaliningrad oblast, as well as a wider area at the border with Poland, to be considered as a local border area. This will avoid fragmentation of existing administrative districts and ensure the inhabitants can move easily without visa requirements. I think this is a very good proposal and I voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Radvilė Morkūnaitė-Mikulėnienė (PPE), in writing. – (LT) With this unprecedented decision – amending a regulation according to the regional needs of a non-EU Member State – the EU is making a special gesture of goodwill towards Russia. I hope that this decision will contribute to developing people-to-people links, so that in the long term, the Kaliningrad region will become a polygon of European modernisation and an example for other Russian regions. I hope that in response, the Russian Federation will strengthen cooperation with relevant EU Member States in areas such as combating organised crime and smuggling (particularly cigarettes produced in the Kaliningrad region and fuel), so that finally, we can anticipate cooperation as regards plans to construct nuclear power plants in the Kaliningrad region and progress in joint projects such as the Nemunas Euroregion. I would also like to remind you that the Kaliningrad region plays a special role in Russian military strategy. While I know that this is a prelude to larger scale decisions, I would point out that a visa waiver is not an EU obligation but a decision based on the progress and reforms made by the country requesting it, which would enable it to be introduced safely. I find it hard to imagine that visa requirements can be lifted in relation to a country whose state structures protect people who are guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity, as is the case with Mikhail Golovatov, nor at a time when Russia refuses to cooperate in such categories of cases as those that took place on 13 January and the Medininkai killings. I therefore hope that Russia will also offer a genuine strategic partnership. It is equally important not to leave behind ENPI countries such as Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which are making significant progress in implementing European reforms.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I welcome this resolution because we must eliminate artificial and arbitrary barriers for people living on both sides of the European Union’s external borders. The Member States have a special role to play in this case and must conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring third countries as a matter of urgency. The implementation of these measures will create a favourable environment for the development of long-term cultural, social and economic links between the inhabitants of the entire region. I believe that this new recast regulation will help to establish better neighbourly relations between the EU and Russia. Moreover, it is clear proof that the EU is respecting its commitment to implementing the principle of freedom of movement and to consistently and actively support people’s right to free movement.

 
  
 		 

  Alfredo Pallone (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of the report on amending the regulation for residents of European Union border areas because, both for neighbouring Member States and for citizens of third countries living along the borders, it is important to facilitate border crossings without the need for visas or any special checks. It is important to implement a regulation that is adapted to the needs of the citizens of these territories, so that they may enjoy a quiet life, and in order to ease both their private lives and commercial ties between small businesses of the areas in question. In particular, the regulation looks at the inclusion in these zones, as outlined above, of the Kaliningrad region and some border territories of Poland.

 
  
 		 

  Georgios Papanikolaou (PPE), in writing. – (EL) The Kaliningrad area, which forms part of the Russian Federation, became an enclave within the EU as a consequence of EU enlargement in 2004 and, since then, has had its ties with neighbouring countries considerably circumscribed. Despite European initiatives to improve the movement of Kaliningrad residents, the specific geographical situation of the area has not prevented the marginalisation of Kaliningrad and its residents. With the present proposal to amend the relevant regulation, and based on Article 15 of the regulation allowing the Member States to introduce measures aimed at easing border crossings for holders of local border traffic permits, the report, which I supported, calls on neighbouring countries (in this case Poland) to take all the necessary measures, such as, for example, the establishment of special border crossings or lanes dedicated exclusively to holders of local border traffic permits, in order to facilitate movements and eliminate the conditions that prevent this traffic and raise new obstacles.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This report is based on the legislative resolution of Parliament, of 1 December 2011, amending the regulation on the inclusion of the Kaliningrad region and certain Polish administrative districts in the eligible border area. The aim is that these regions will benefit from the regulation that sets out rules for local border traffic on the land borders of the Member States and amends the provisions of the Schengen Agreement. This measure prevents the creation of barriers to social and cultural interchange and regional cooperation with neighbours, as well as preventing the creation of barriers to trade, while also preserving the security of the entire Schengen area. I voted in favour for these reasons.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council concerns rules on local border traffic at the external borders of the Member States, which enables them to derogate from the rules on border checks for neighbouring countries, as it is not necessary to present a visa, proof of sufficient means of subsistence or proof of the purpose of the stay in these exceptional cases. This derogation from the regulation is based on the desire to ensure good relations between peoples, without centuries-old economic, social and cultural ties between the different communities coming undone. This is the case in the region of Kaliningrad, called Königsberg in German, which was part of the Soviet Union between 1945 and 1992, and since then has belonged to the Russian Federation, with a natural border with the Baltic Sea, and land borders with Poland and Lithuania. Extending the border area up to 50 km, from the 30 km cited in the regulation, is therefore justified, in order to avoid the breakdown of a single region into several artificial areas.

As such, I voted in favour, in the hope that the agreement will help to facilitate relations between the two spaces, which were been hampered by the EU enlargement in 2004.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. On 20 December 2006, the European Parliament and Council adopted Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006 laying down rules on local border traffic at the external land borders of the Member States (hereafter: the regulation), which enables Member States to derogate from the general rules on border checks laid down in the Schengen Borders Code for persons living in a border area, including visa requirement, the need to have sufficient means of subsistence as well as the need to prove the purpose of the stay. The objective of this regulation is to prevent the creation of barriers to trade, social and cultural interchange or regional cooperation with neighbours.

 
  
 		 

  Tokia Saïfi (PPE), in writing. – (FR) The Kaliningrad enclave is the only one on European Union territory. In 2006, the Council and the European Parliament adopted a regulation laying down rules on local border traffic at the external land borders of the Member States, which enables Member States to derogate from the general rules on border checks laid down in the Schengen Borders Code for persons living in a border area. Under the regulation, Member States may conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring countries that are not members of the European Union. Local border traffic makes life much easier for persons living close to external land borders. There is little evidence of abuse. Applying the rules that are normally used to define border areas would artificially divide this enclave. This text authorises the enlargement of the ‘border area’, thereby facilitating and increasing the amount of economic and cultural exchanges between Kaliningrad, on the one hand, and the main centres in northern Poland, on the other. I voted in favour of this modification to the regulation as I believe that European legislation and regulations must be adapted to the realities on the ground.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation became an enclave within the EU as a consequence of the EU enlargement in 2004 and since then, has had its ties with its neighbours considerably circumscribed. There have been a number of EU initiatives in the last few years to facilitate the movement of Kaliningrad residents. Among the various measures that have been adopted, there is the establishment of a Facilitated Rail Transit Document for travel between Kaliningrad and mainland Russia. Furthermore, in 2007, the EU and Russia entered into the Visa Facilitation Agreement, which simplifies the issuance of short-term visas for all Russian nationals travelling to Schengen countries. Local border areas constitute a very important tool developed by the European Union to ensure that artificial and arbitrary barriers are not erected between peoples living in regions divided by national frontiers. Member States must therefore conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring third countries with the objective of promoting sustained contacts between the peoples living on either side of the European Union’s external frontiers.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) The expansion of the EU means that the Kaliningrad area in the Russian Federation has become an enclave within the EU. Around 1 million people live in three districts completely surrounded by EU territory. These people now encounter stringent transit and visa requirements when they wish to travel to Poland or to the main part of Russia. Council Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006 sets down rules for local border traffic and external land borders of Member States (relating to a zone of 30 km) that are an exception to the provisions of the Schengen Agreement. In order to implement this regulation, the affected countries can conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring third countries in order to take the special conditions sufficiently into account. The EU has introduced initiatives in an effort to make it easier for those living in the area to commute between Kaliningrad and the Russian mainland. Thus far, however, these initiatives have proven inadequate. Poland and the Russian Federation have now petitioned for an amendment to Council Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006: as an exception, the border area is to be extended to 50 km so that the whole Kaliningrad area would be designated a border area. The Commission recommends that the regulation should be amended accordingly. I have also voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Zbigniew Ziobro (EFD), in writing. – (PL) The report we have voted on reveals an unequal treatment of partners. All residents of the Kaliningrad region have the opportunity of crossing the border; meanwhile, on the Polish side, only a 50 km wide section of the border area is covered by the visa-free travel programme. This harmful inequality must be resolved by extending the zone to cover the entire voivodship, and by discussing this issue at the next EU-Russia meeting.

Unfortunately, the resolution also fails to mention the possibility of the movement of commercial and tourist vessels through the Pilawa Strait onto the Vistula Spit. Currently, the Russian side wants to limit the right of innocent passage with regard to the category of the straits. I think that we as the Union should seek to compensate for inequalities in the treatment of the inhabitants of the regions bordering the Kaliningrad region and provide the entire population of the voivodship, not just of selected districts, with the opportunity to enter the Kaliningrad region freely.

 
  
  

Recommendation: Hannes Swoboda (A7-0390/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for the conclusion of the Treaty concerning the Accession of Croatia, and I see this treaty as a positive political factor in European integration. I would, however, draw attention to the need to strengthen European policies aimed at cohesion and the socio-economic and territorial convergence of the EU, without which, EU enlargement may have undesirable results.

 
  
 		 

  Roberta Angelilli (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I abstained in the vote on Croatia’s request to join the European Union. There is no doubt that Croatia has made significant progress in recent years on reforming its legal system and public administration, fighting corruption and organised crime, and protecting the rights of minorities. However, I am sure that much remains to be done in remembrance of the huge ethnic cleansing of the Italian population carried out between 1945 and 1948 by the militia of the Croatian authorities of the former Yugoslavian communist regime. Above all, no commitment has been made to recognise the rights of exiles, starting with the property that was confiscated during those years.

 
  
 		 

  Pino Arlacchi (S&D), in writing. – I voted for this resolution because I fully support the conclusion of the accession negotiations for EU membership with Croatia. I believe that Croatian membership will make the EU stronger, will enrich its culture, and will make an important contribution giving a positive impetus to the process of European integration. I also would like to stress the need for Croatia to keep up the reform momentum and to continue with the same vigour and hard work also after the conclusion of the negotiations and beyond accession. While acknowledging the good progress made, Croatia should continue to implement reform of the judiciary and facilitate the return of refugees and displaced persons, paying special attention to the situation of ethnic Serbian returnees. In addition to that, Croatian authorities should strengthen the administrative capacities of anti-corruption bodies and foster a culture of political, public sector and judicial accountability as a prerequisite for reinforcing the rule of law.

 
  
 		 

  Sophie Auconie (PPE), in writing. – (FR) The process for Croatia’s accession to the EU began in 2003 when the country submitted its application to the European Commission. The last 10 years of negotiations have enabled it to prepare for membership of the European Union. I welcome the support given by the European Parliament, which sought to send a strong signal to Croatia. The country will become the 28th member of the EU on 1 July 2013.

 
  
 		 

  Zoltán Bagó (PPE), in writing. – (HU) Croatia’s EU accession negotiations have been ongoing for six years. The Group of the European People’s Party and Hungary strongly supported Croatia’s accession during these negotiations. With my vote, I, too, expressed the fact that I agree with the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union and with the Council decision accepting the application for accession.

The Council formulated the draft Accession Treaty in agreement with Hungary. Hungarian interests have been incorporated into the document over the course of a drafting process which lasted more than one year. According to the schedule, Croatia may become the 28th EU Member State as of 1 July 2013.

However, I would like to stress the need for further cooperation on the part of Croatia with the ICTY (the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia), for increasing the efficiency of the justice system, and for continuing the fight against corruption and organised crime.

 
  
 		 

  Maria Da Graça Carvalho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I welcome the enlargement of the European Union through the accession of the Republic of Croatia. Croatia has prepared very well for accession, which implies lasting respect for the values on which the EU is based, as well as a commitment to promoting them. Croatia fulfils the political criteria, and it is expected that this country will meet the economic criteria and those of the acquis for its accession on 1 July 2013.

 
  
 		 

  David Casa (PPE), in writing. – Croatia has been an independent nation for twenty years now and an EU accession candidate for eight. The country has successfully met the required criteria to become a fully-fledged Member State. The accession process has helped consolidate democracy and has mobilised other sweeping political, social and economic reforms in Croatia. The nation’s accession is important both to the EU and to the Balkan region in general. I support the rapporteur and believe that Croatia should be accepted as a Member State on 1 July 2013 as long as it continues the improvements made thus far. Until this date, I encourage Croatia to continue to step up its prosecution of war criminals, better facilitate the return of refugees, improve women’s equality in regard to equal pay and representation in political institutions and improve LGBT rights due to the violence demonstrated at the LGBT pride march in June 2011.

 
  
 		 

  Ioan Enciu (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted in favour of Croatia’s accession to the European Union as I feel that this country has met all the conditions, both political and economic, to be able to become a member of the EU. Croatia’s accession helps the European Union prove that it remains receptive and capable of maintaining a genuine, constructive dialogue with its immediate neighbours. This is an extremely important consideration, especially during the current crisis the EU is going through, forcing it to become introverted. Dialogue and openness, both fundamental values of the EU, must remain benchmarks not only in its external relations and in issues such as immigration, but also with regard to internal European dynamics. This dialogue and openness should help kick-start the EU’s integration by rejecting nationalistic or xenophobic behaviour.

 
  
 		 

  Edite Estrela (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I voted for this recommendation as it advocates the accession of Croatia to the European Union. This opens the way to the signing of the Treaty of Accession on 8 December, and its subsequent ratification by the 27 Member States. However, Croatia needs to address the challenges that it is currently facing, in particular, with regard to its judicial system and the fight against corruption and organised crime.

 
  
 		 

  Diogo Feio (PPE), in writing. – (PT) In February 2010, I wrote that Croatia had been undeniably successful in fulfilling the criteria for membership, and that it had made an effort to continue along this path, despite the additional difficulties that it had to face in view of the international situation, and that Croatia was a good example for other countries wishing to become part of the European Union. Fortunately, Croatia has not deviated from this path, so that, in accordance with the criteria established by the EU, it is now ready to join this community of Member States and peoples. I welcome the Croatian people and their institutions at this important time in its history and in our common European history, and I hope that Croatia’s accession to the EU will provide a new impetus for reform to the Balkan countries that are not yet part of the EU, and to the EU itself.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This proposal for a recommendation, drafted by Mr Swoboda, focuses on the Treaty concerning the Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, one of the three instruments that make up the process of accession of a country to the EU: treaty, protocol and final act. The accession of Croatia to the EU is a moment of great importance for Europe, and represents another step forward in the process of bringing stability to the Balkans. For Croatia, this phase does not represent the end of the process, but only the successful completion of one more stage. I would point out that this accession is an historic moment for Europe, as was evident in the enthusiasm with which Parliament applauded the adoption of the proposal for Croatia’s accession. As we are looking at a ‘happy marriage’ – the EU has an interest in its enlargement into the Balkans, and Croatia has much to gain from its accession to the single market – I welcome the accession of Croatia to the EU and hope that the Croatian Government will continue the process of democratisation and reform that is already under way, thus contributing to the principles which underlie the construction of the single market.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) The decision on Croatia’s accession, or that of any other country, to the European Union must come, first and foremost, from the free expression of the sovereign will of this country’s people. This is all the more important in the knowledge that this free expression – which, of course, involves a deep, participatory and informed discussion and decision – was not always ensured in other cases in the past.

We should neither ignore nor underestimate the meaning, nature and aims of this process of integration. The experience of other countries, including Portugal, shows us that the process of capitalist integration embodied by the EU involves the destruction of productive capacity and employment, the country’s increasing dependence, a disadvantageous, subordinated position which is peripheral to the process of the international division of labour, the loss of sovereignty over key elements which would have allowed our people to realise their wishes and aspirations, and which are absolutely essential to their free collective self-determination.

However, the internationalisation of the economy, the international division of labour, the growing cooperation between Member States and the processes of integration correspond to realities and trends of development which are not unique to capitalism. We are therefore fighting for this other Europe – a Europe that is not only possible, but also increasingly necessary.

 
  
 		 

  Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) It is up to the Croatian people, in the first place, to make the decision as to whether or not to join the EU. The Portuguese experience shows us that the EU’s process of capitalist integration has meant, and still means, first and foremost, the destruction of productive capacity and employment, the growing dependence of the country on the major powers of the EU, and a loss of sovereignty on key elements that would have allowed our people to realise their wishes and aspirations.

As the integration of economies is a dialectical necessity, its development within the framework of the capitalist system and the unequal development that this entails only favours the major powers and monopolies, particularly financial monopolies, impoverishing countries and peoples, sacrificing democracy and impeding the fight for economic and social systems that make work and human wellbeing their first and only priority.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) Twenty years after declaring independence, and almost eight years after applying for membership of the EU, Croatia has reached an historic milestone, with the successful completion of the accession talks and the country now in the process of joining the EU, and these successes deserve unconditional acknowledgement. The accession process is making a substantial contribution to Croatia’s transformation into a solid and mature democratic country whose membership can strengthen the Union, enrich its European culture and heritage and make a major contribution to preserving the credibility of the expansion process. Despite considerable progress, however, I firmly believe that it is important to continue with the reforms initiated, that it is necessary to focus particularly on commitments undertaken in the area of the judiciary, internal affairs and basic rights – including the protection of media freedom, the impartial resolution of war crimes cases, the fight against corruption, protection of minorities, border controls, police cooperation, the fight against organised crime and judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters – as well as on commitments undertaken in the area of competition policy. Croatia’s determination to combat corruption, and also the progress achieved in the area of women’s rights and gender equality, for example, are pleasing. It is desirable for Croatia to continue consolidating good neighbourly relations, to continue as an important and active promoter of regional cooperation at all levels, and to back up its efforts towards membership with steps that will be economically, socially and generally beneficial to all citizens of this region.

 
  
 		 

  Pat the Cope Gallagher (ALDE), in writing. – (GA) I fully support the accession of Croatia to the European Union. The next step is for the Member States and for Croatia, following a national referendum, to sign the Accession Treaty. It is thought that Croatia will accede to the EU on 1 July 2013.

 
  
 		 

  Bruno Gollnisch (NI), in writing. – (FR) Croatia is, without doubt, a European country by dint of its geography, culture, history and population. We should all welcome the fact that we have been able to maintain a close relationship with the country. However, the European project as it stands cannot be the framework for this relationship. It is, in fact, developing into a centralised, supranational state, bypassing the peoples and the national parliaments, imposing its ultraliberal, globalist diktats, and conferring on itself the right to dictate the budgets of the Member States and, as a consequence, all of their actions, with its eyes firmly fixed on satisfying the markets rather than on people’s wellbeing. I understand the symbolic value, for the people of Croatia, of accession to the European Union. However, I also know that they will soon become disenchanted. The benefits that they will derive from membership will be far fewer than they had hoped, and the restrictions far more intolerable than they had expected. Ask the Greeks, the Irish and the Portuguese what they think about it now. I would not sell any of my friends a ticket to board the Titanic. That is why I abstained.

 
  
 		 

  Mathieu Grosch (PPE), in writing. – (DE) I abstained from voting on the report because although the country has already made enormous efforts, it has not managed to meet the necessary criteria.

The EU should be making every effort to work together more effectively and to strengthen its social and economic policy, rather than admitting new members and giving rise to false hopes in these countries, as it did, for example, in those countries that most recently joined the EU. This may make Europe bigger, but it will certainly not succeed in making it better or stronger.

 
  
 		 

  Juozas Imbrasas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I welcomed this document and the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia and, notably, the Council decision accepting the application for accession, but the Commission must monitor further preparations for accession with rigour and objectivity and help the Croatian authorities fulfil the commitments and obligations they entered into in the negotiations. The Commission must also keep Parliament regularly informed of the extent to which the Croatian authorities are honouring their commitments in order to fully assume their membership obligations upon accession to the EU on 1 July 2013.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I voted against Croatian admission to the EU at this time.

 
  
 		 

  Clemente Mastella (PPE), in writing. – (IT) We take the view that the conditions set out for the admission of Croatia to the European Union have been completely met. Parliament must be consulted on any substantial modifications to the draft Treaty. We also think that the Commission will play a crucial role by carefully, rigorously and objectively monitoring further preparations for accession and by helping the Croatian authorities to fulfil the commitments and obligations assumed during negotiations. We expect the Commission to keep Parliament regularly informed of the measures taken by the Croatian authorities to honour their commitments and to fully assume their membership obligations upon accession, scheduled for 1 July 2013.

 
  
 		 

  Véronique Mathieu (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I abstained from the vote on Croatia’s application for accession to the European Union. Indeed, this report consents to the Republic of Croatia becoming a member of the European Union. Although the Commission is required to report regularly to Parliament on the extent to which the Croatian authorities are honouring their commitments in order to fulfil the obligations incumbent on them when Croatia joins the EU on 1 July 2013, I personally believe that the crisis that the European Union is experiencing is sufficiently serious as to suspend the accession process. The European Union’s current Member States, in particular, those in the euro area, must be in a strong enough position to accommodate a new member, with all the advantages and disadvantages it will bring. The current efforts of the Heads of State or Government to build the future of the EU are evidence of the urgent need to consolidate our acquis. Moreover, I would expect the European Commission to take special measures to obtain guarantees regarding the fight against corruption.

 
  
 		 

  Mario Mauro (PPE), in writing. – (IT) In light of the fact that Croatia has now shown that it meets the accession requirements, I am in favour of approving the accession request. I would add that this is a truly important event for the European Union and for the entire Balkans area.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted for the accession of Croatia to the European Union. It meets all the criteria for accession to the EU, dubbed the Copenhagen criteria: the existence of the Rule of Law, stable institutions that ensure democracy, respect for human rights and the protection of minorities, the existence of a functioning market economy, and the ability to cope with competitive pressure and EU market forces. As it is able to meet the obligations of membership, including sharing the objectives of the political, economic and monetary union, Croatia’s joining the 27 Member States also symbolises the solidarity of the EU in its efforts to send a positive signal to the Balkans.

 
  
 		 

  Willy Meyer (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (ES) My group has always been in favour of Croatia and any other country being able to join the European Union, as long as they fulfil the established requirements. This is why I voted in favour of this report, because it approves Croatia’s accession to the EU.

 
  
 		 

  Louis Michel (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) Since its independence, Croatia has shown its desire to build a solid relationship with the European Union. This is demonstrated by the reform of its administrative system and its ever greater efforts to combat corruption. Croatia must continue with these efforts, as its accession, scheduled for July 2013, is not the end of the process, but rather the start of a long and increasingly close relationship. A support mechanism will have to be maintained as part of a relationship of trust between the European Union and Croatia. This will ensure that the details of Croatia’s accession are favourable to each party. In the future, Zagreb will have to make further efforts to combat corruption and organised crime, among other things; it will have to tackle the issue of legal reforms, prosecute war criminals, encourage the return of refugees and ensure compliance with all of the recommendations of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY). As Mr Barroso so rightly said, enlargement is a question of credibility. I am convinced that Croatia will be a credible and trustworthy 28th Member State.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – I welcome the signing of Croatia’s Accession Treaty and regard it as proof of credibility of EU enlargement policy: hard work and reforms take some time, but pay off ultimately! S&D is looking forward to the arrival of Croatian observers to the EP. In favour.

 
  
 		 

  Andreas Mölzer (NI), in writing. – (DE) The accession of Croatia to the European Union is an important step. In recent years, Croatia has worked continuously to implement the reforms demanded by the EU in the accession negotiations and to thereby meet all the accession criteria. In addition, there can be no doubt that Croatia is part of the European cultural community characterised by a Christian tradition, so that integration in the European Union would seem to be desirable. It should also be emphasised that, unlike Turkey, Croatia has always pushed forward with the promised reforms. This would indicate that the inclusion of the people of Croatia will give the EU another Member State it can rely upon at European level. The accession of Croatia is also an important step towards the integration of the countries of the Western Balkans. For these reasons, I have voted in favour of Croatia’s accession.

 
  
 		 

  Vital Moreira (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of Croatia’s accession to the European Union as I believe that this country completely fulfils the condition for membership of the Union, starting with the Copenhagen criteria, which are now explicitly mentioned in the Treaty on European Union, in particular, with regard to democracy, human rights, an independent judiciary, good governance, protection of minorities, market economy and competition, social protection, and so on.

Following the early accession of Bulgaria and Romania, which were clearly not yet ready to do so, it has been important to ensure that new countries that join are better prepared and less swayed by political expediency. The EU has already had too many problems in trying to spare itself the difficulties of coping with the entry of new countries that do not meet the conditions necessary for full integration into all areas of European integration, such as the internal market, social Europe, the area of freedom, security and justice, and external policy.

 
  
 		 

  Radvilė Morkūnaitė-Mikulėnienė (PPE), in writing. – (LT) Today, the European Parliament adopted an historic decision, consenting to the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia and the Council decision accepting Croatia’s application for accession. I hope that Croatia will continue to keep up the good progress it has made in meeting the commitments it entered into during the negotiations. I am pleased that Lithuania, the country I come from, and Croatia will be linked by history given that Croatia’s accession to the EU is due to take place on 1 July 2013 during Lithuania’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union. I hope that here in the European Parliament, we will soon be able to congratulate our parliamentary observer colleagues from Croatia.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I welcome this resolution, which consents to the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia. However, the Commission must continue to monitor further preparations for accession with rigour and objectivity. Croatia must guarantee the stability of institutions safeguarding democracy, the rule of law and human rights and properly satisfy economic and legal requirements. Consequently, it is very important to ensure that the Croatian authorities are given full assistance so that they are able to properly fulfil the commitments and obligations they entered into during the negotiations.

 
  
 		 

  Alfredo Pallone (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Parliament has approved the Council’s recommendation on the admission of Croatia to the EU, thanks, in part, to my vote in favour. After eight years of negotiations, we have finally arrived at the decisive moment when the Croatian people will decide in a referendum next year whether their country will be part of the EU from 2013 onwards. Croatia must be recognised for having reached an historic goal in its process of integration, successfully concluding accession negotiations with the EU after having satisfied requirements in relation to the legal system, the protection of fundamental rights and fighting corruption. All these achievements are worthy of unreserved recognition.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted for the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union as, based on the reports presented to Parliament, I believe that the conditions for the admission of the candidate country have been fulfilled. I would, however, point out the Commission’s duty to monitor the remaining preparations for accession closely and objectively, and to help the Croatian authorities meet the commitments and obligations that they took on in the negotiations. I would also highlight the need for the Commission to keep Parliament regularly informed about the extent to which the Croatian authorities are honouring their commitments, so that they can take on all their obligations as a Member State when the country joins the EU on 1 July 2013.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted for the approval of Croatia’s accession to the European Union as all of the conditions for accession to the common area are found to have been met, and the Committee on Foreign Affairs has not raised any objections.

 
  
 		 

  Frédérique Ries (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) By consenting to Croatia’s accession to the European Union, the European Parliament has paved the way for the start of the country’s accession process and its ratification by the 27 Member States of the current European club. This agreement should be ratified at the European Council on 9 December with a view to Croatia’s official accession on 1 July 2013. Of course, now is not the time to hold celebrations such as those that marked the enlargement ceremonies held when 10 new countries joined the Union on 1 June 2004. However, it is important to welcome this jewel of the Mediterranean in a fitting manner; in other words, enthusiastically and firmly. A spontaneous accession, rather than accession by default, is needed, given the efforts made by Croatia’s people, and given, too, its standard of living and the economic situation in Croatia, both of which are much better than the indicators for other countries were when they joined. The crisis that has reigned in the Union since 2009 also implies the need for a firm stance towards new members, who have to become part of a virtuous circle: tight budgets and relentless efforts to combat corruption and to promote transparency. This, too, is a message that the Croatian authorities must hear.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. The EP has today given its broad support to Croatian membership, recognising the huge progress made towards reforms by Croatia. The process of reform is not over, however, and Croatia should continue on its reform path. This is particularly true in the areas of justice reform, anti-corruption reforms, minority protection and the prosecution of war crimes. The EP has today also criticised the crackdown on the last Gay Pride Parade in Split, in spite of efforts by the EPP to muzzle this criticism. The EP must now continue to monitor the situation to ensure Croatia implements all reforms and that the EU Commission properly oversees this. To this end, the Greens believe the EP should be given the role of assessing the 6-monthly monitoring reports on Croatia’s progress. MEPs also have an important role to convince EU citizens that continuing the enlargement process in the Western Balkans is in the interest of all in Europe.

 
  
 		 

  Tokia Saïfi (PPE), in writing. – (FR) In the last few years, Croatia, which has been in accession negotiations with the European Union since 2005, has implemented radical structural reforms enabling it to meet EU membership requirements. Major reforms have been carried out with a view to promoting job creation, increasing competitiveness and strengthening fiscal policies. Many challenges remain, and the Croatian authorities must continue their reforms, particularly their judicial reforms, to combat corruption and organised crime. In order to heal the wounds of the past, Croatia needs to redouble its efforts to prosecute war criminals, follow the set of recommendations made by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and encourage the return of war refugees, especially the Serbs. Croatia’s forthcoming accession is a positive signal for the region as a whole; it is a sign that reforms pay, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

 
  
 		 

  József Szájer (PPE), in writing. – (HU) As we all remember, the EU accession of Croatia was a special priority of the Hungarian EU Presidency programme. Therefore, at this historic moment when we decided with an overwhelming majority in favour of Croatia becoming a full Member State of the EU, I consider it particularly important to highlight the immense efforts made by the Hungarian Presidency for the conclusion of the accession negotiations.

I am pleased to note that the Hungarians’ commitment has borne fruit. With the European Parliament approving Croatia’s accession today, we have opened a new chapter in the life of the EU. Enlargement is undeniable proof of the strength of European integration. At the same time, we must not forget that the ratification of the Accession Treaty by the Member States, and the Croatian referendum, still lie before us; however, if everything proceeds as planned, Croatia may join the European Union in July 2013.

I am of the opinion that today’s decision is beneficial for all parties concerned. Accession is not only of enormous significance for Croatia, but is also of strategic importance for Hungary and all the countries in the region. At the same time, I also hope that this enlargement will be able to give new impetus to the EU project as well.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Croatia’s accession to the European Union is a very positive sign for the Balkans. Croatia has achieved the set of political and economic criteria set out at the Copenhagen European Council in 1993, as well as the adaptation and implementation of the EU acquis, as described in the Commission’s opinion of October 2011.

The accession of Croatia to the EU on 1 July 2013 will set an example for other Balkan countries, showing that efforts to comply with the Copenhagen criteria can bear fruit. In the specific case of Croatia, issues such as the fight against corruption, the independent judiciary, and the pursuit of war criminals and cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia has led to negotiations dragging on since 2003, when Croatia made its first request to join the EU.

I congratulate the Croatian authorities for their efforts, but I would also like to emphasise that the rules should be equally applied to all candidate and potential candidate countries.

 
  
 		 

  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the European Parliament legislative resolution of 1 December 2011 on the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union because I support the Republic of Croatia’s accession to the European Union. The Commission must continue to monitor the preparations for accession rigorously and objectively and assist the Croatian authorities in meeting their commitments and obligations, as assumed during the negotiations. Furthermore, the Commission must inform Parliament on a regular basis about the extent to which the Croatian authorities are honouring their commitments, with a view to assuming fully the obligations arising from being a member when it joins, on 1 July 2013. We should point out that Parliament has to be consulted on any substantial modification to the draft Treaty on the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. We are expecting more active participation from Croatia as of 1 July 2013 in the development and implementation of the EU’s macro-regional strategies, especially the EU strategy for the Danube region.

 
  
 		 

  Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR), in writing. – While I am generally in favour of enlargement of the EU, it is clear that the lessons of other recent accessions have not been learned. In relation to Croatia, there is still widespread corruption, organised crime has not been dealt with, the judiciary is often ineffective and property and contract laws do not function properly. On this basis, I abstained on these votes.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) According to Article 49 of the Treaty on European Union, the European Parliament must agree to any expansion of the European Union. I voted in favour because Croatia meets the Copenhagen criteria for full membership of the Union. Until the country’s definitive accession, the Commission will continue to monitor the development of the initiated reform process and report on this to the European Parliament.

 
  
 		 

  Hermann Winkler (PPE), in writing. – (DE) The EU has undergone a period of rapid growth in recent years. Twelve new Member States have acceded since 2004. Unfortunately, all the euphoria at the expansion in the East has meant that warnings have been ignored, as in the case of Bulgaria and Romania recently. As a result of the debt crisis, the EU is currently undergoing its greatest test since its foundation. Consolidation must take precedence over expansion if we are to preserve the European project. A ‘no’ at this point is not aimed at the Croatian people and the efforts of large parts of the population, but rather a vote in favour of stabilising the Union. For these reasons, I have voted against the accession of Croatia.

 
  
  

Report: Hannes Swoboda (A7-0389/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for this report. Croatia should continue with its reforms, in particular, in relation to the fight against corruption and the integration of refugees. The conclusion of the new accession process and the principle of ratifying the Treaty of Accession should in no way impede the reforms that are under way.

 
  
 		 

  Zoltán Bagó (PPE), in writing. – (HU) The conclusion of Croatia’s accession negotiations marks the end of a six-year process. According to the resolution, the European Parliament supports the signing of the Accession Treaty and I, too, have expressed the same opinion with my positive vote.

The conclusion of Croatia’s accession negotiations strengthens the credibility of the EU enlargement process, while the prospect of extending European integration facilitates peace in third countries and the establishment of good neighbourhood relations. In the Western Balkans region, there is still a great need for this today, especially during an economic crisis of this magnitude.

During the process of accession, it is extremely important for a country to be judged on the basis of its own achievements, and that Member States refrain from allowing bilateral disputes to influence the process.

I agree that Croatia still needs to fulfil its commitments made during the negotiations, for example, in respect of internal affairs, the reform of the judicial system, and fundamental rights. In the fight against corruption, it should strengthen the capacities of its administrative bodies.

 
  
 		 

  Regina Bastos (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Twenty years after its declaration of independence, and roughly eight years since it submitted its application for membership to the EU, Croatia has successfully completed negotiations for EU membership. While the accession process has played a significant role in the transformation of Croatia into a solid democracy, Croatia’s accession will also make the EU stronger and will have broad implications at European and regional level, giving a positive boost to the process of European integration both in the EU and in the Western Balkans.

This report, for which I voted, emphasises the need for Croatia to maintain momentum in its reforms, keeping up the same intensity and determination following the conclusion of negotiations and accession. It encourages Croatia to continue to carry out its reform of the judiciary, in line with the recommendations of the Commission. However, the Croatian authorities should continue to increase the administrative capacity of bodies that are fighting against corruption, particularly with regard to best practice in the EU.

 
  
 		 

  Maria Da Graça Carvalho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I welcome the conclusion of accession negotiations with Croatia, putting an end to almost six years of negotiations and several years of preparation, which have changed the socio-political, economic and cultural landscape of the country considerably. It is necessary to maintain the momentum of reforms, as this process is not complete. I would call for the same intensity and determination to be maintained following the conclusion of negotiations and accession.

 
  
 		 

  Carlos Coelho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The enlargement of the EU is one of the most effective instruments of its external policy and one of the best proofs of its success. Several countries want to join the EU, and none want to leave. During its history, the EU has grown from six to 27 Member States, and this has created some problems for the way in which it functions. I agree with the many who therefore argue that it is important that the three Copenhagen criteria be supplemented by a fourth: knowing whether the EU is able to integrate another candidate country.

In addition to there being doubts about Croatia’s readiness in some areas of the Rule of Law, I consider it unwise, especially in this time of crisis, to overstretch the EU by increasing the number of Member States. I would also point out that unanimity is required, especially when amending the Treaties, which have been discussed a great deal recently. I cannot therefore vote for the recommendation on Croatia’s accession to the EU at this point.

 
  
 		 

  Lara Comi (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The accession of Croatia to the European Union from 1 July 2013 is the apotheosis of eight years of negotiations that deserve the utmost recognition, given the transformation of Croatia into a robust and mature democracy based on the founding values of the European Union. I hope that Croatia’s accession will act as a catalyst for reform in the Western Balkan countries. This event will enable Croatia and its citizens to take full advantage of the rights and guarantees provided for by the EU Treaties. Beyond these rights, the Croatian authorities must respect the commitments it has taken in the negotiations and encourage representatives of civil society to play a role in the entire accession process. Meanwhile, further support through the pre-accession instrument ought to facilitate adaptation to the reforms that are undertaken. However, my vote in favour of this report also serves to emphasise the need to proceed with the reforms geared towards ensuring that the magistracy is impartial and transparent on all forms of corruption and international organised crime. I would also encourage tighter cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY), particularly in terms of the pursuit of war criminals and the integration of political refugees.

 
  
 		 

  Christine De Veyrac (PPE), in writing. – (FR) Croatia’s accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, which is supported by the European Parliament, will make it possible to strengthen the EU area of prosperity and stability in South-East Europe, a region that witnessed the last open conflict on European soil. Croatia’s accession will help to maintain the credibility of the enlargement process and will serve as an encouragement for the other countries in the Western Balkans region that are on the path to European integration.

 
  
 		 

  Diogo Feio (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I would like to reiterate what I said in 2010: I hope that the entry of Croatia into the European Union will be seen in the Balkans as a sign of hope, and that the other countries in the region, particularly Serbia, will recognise the national and international advantages and benefits of opting for Europe. Given the objective confirmation that Croatia has complied with the criteria for accession, it is time to accept its request for entry into the EU and welcome Croatians to our common ‘family’. At a time that is not proving easy for any country in Europe, it is reassuring to see that the generous idea underlying our process of integration is still able to attract other European countries, and that, despite its problems, the European way is the best route for us to take together.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This report, drafted by Mr Swoboda, focuses on Croatia’s application, which merits the agreement of the Council, as does the draft Treaty concerning the Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, the Protocol and the Final Act. All of the conditions have therefore been met for Croatia to accede to the European Union from 1 January 2013, becoming its 28th Member State. This is a very long process, the final stages of which have only been possible due to the determination of all the politicians involved and a consistent EU policy. Only through this process have there been significant steps taken in the relations between Croatia and Serbia. However, this process does not end on 9 December with the signing of the Treaty of Accession in Brussels. Although much has been done, particularly in terms of combating corruption, much remains still to do, especially in relation to human rights, the consolidation of the Rule of Law and the fulfilment of all the criteria of the Copenhagen Agreement. I am therefore voting for this report and I welcome the way in which this process has been conducted, as it sets an example for other candidate countries for accession to the EU to follow.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) We believe that the decision on Croatia’s accession, or that of any other country, to the European Union must, first and foremost, come from the free expression of the sovereign will of this country’s people. Having said that, we should naturally neither ignore nor underestimate the meaning, nature and aims of this process of integration.

The report lists a range of obligations with which Croatia must comply. We are facing the unravelling of the arguments and the neoliberal blueprint upon which this EU keeps insisting. The rhetoric of sacrosanct free competition and ‘social market economy’, a euphemistic expression for the capitalist economy is, in fact, increasingly antisocial, as experience strongly bears out.

The EU cannot have a prosperous future if, as this report demonstrates, it regulates its every action in terms of enlargements and other structuring policies through multinationals’ access to markets and raw materials, imposing destructive policies on productive sectors and on employment. For all of these reasons, we abstained from voting.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) Twenty years after declaring independence, and almost eight years after applying for membership of the EU, Croatia has reached an historic milestone, with the successful completion of the accession talks and the country now in the process of joining the EU, and these successes deserve unconditional acknowledgement. The accession process is making a substantial contribution to Croatia’s transformation into a solid and mature democratic country whose membership can strengthen the Union, enrich its European culture and heritage and make a major contribution to preserving the credibility of the expansion process. Despite considerable progress, however, I firmly believe that it is important to continue with the reforms initiated, that it is necessary to focus particularly on commitments undertaken in the area of the judiciary, internal affairs and basic rights – including the protection of media freedom, the impartial resolution of war crimes cases, the fight against corruption, protection of minorities, border controls, police cooperation, the fight against organised crime and judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters – as well as on commitments undertaken in the area of competition policy. Croatia’s determination to combat corruption, and also the progress achieved in the area of women’s rights and gender equality, for example, are pleasing. It is desirable for Croatia to continue consolidating good neighbourly relations, to continue as an important and active promoter of regional cooperation at all levels, and to back up its efforts towards membership with steps that will be economically, socially and generally beneficial to all citizens of this region.

 
  
 		 

  Pat the Cope Gallagher (ALDE), in writing. – (GA) I fully support the accession of Croatia to the European Union. The next step is for the Member States and for Croatia to sign the Accession Treaty following a national referendum. It is thought that Croatia will accede to the EU on 1 July 2013.

 
  
 		 

  Robert Goebbels (S&D), in writing. – (FR) I abstained from voting on Croatia’s accession. Croatia is clearly a State destined to become a member of the European Union. However, this latest enlargement comes at the worst possible time. The Union’s budget is woeful. The financial perspective is heading towards further austerity. Moreover, and most importantly, the Union does not yet have the regulations necessary for it to function better and to take swifter decisions. The European commotion will only get worse if we move from 27 to 28 States.

 
  
 		 

  Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) The great tradition of European integration continues. Following the European Parliament’s vote in favour of Croatia’s accession, the EU is preparing to welcome its 28th member. By voting in favour, I wanted to show my support for the accession of a country whose history and culture, but also, and above all, its geography, make it European through and through. Not so long ago, the Balkans were entrenched in war. Since then, the countries of the former Yugoslavia have made rapid progress along the path of reform and integration. Of course, Croatia still has a long way to go before it meets EU standards, but with this vote, the European Parliament has just reaffirmed Zagreb’s EU aspirations.

 
  
 		 

  Sylvie Guillaume (S&D), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of Croatia’s accession to the EU; the country should thus become the 28th member of the EU by 1 July 2013 at the latest. Clearly, between now and then, Croatia must continue its efforts to guarantee its membership. In recent years, Croatia has implemented reforms that have helped make its institutions more transparent and accountable. Despite the severity of the crisis, the country is investing in policies to create green jobs and undertaking ambitious reforms. This positive vote therefore serves to confirm the legitimacy of Croatia’s accession to the EU and rewards its efforts to date.

 
  
 		 

  Juozas Imbrasas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this document because accession negotiations with Croatia have now been concluded, bringing to an end almost six years of negotiation and several years of preparation that have significantly altered the country’s socio-political, economic and cultural landscape. Reforms must continue, however, and I believe that this process is not complete but should continue with the same vigour and hard work after the conclusion of the negotiations and beyond accession. The positive results of this process will strengthen support for EU membership among Croatia’s citizens, as well as their trust in it, and will encourage people to participate in the EU referendum and support the signing of the Accession Treaty. I welcome the signing of the Accession Treaty, and all EU Member States should now complete its ratification in a timely manner.

 
  
 		 

  Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I support Croatia’s accession to the European Union and welcome the important steps which have been taken towards this. Hannes Swoboda’s report welcomes the conclusion of the accession negotiations and calls on Croatia to organise a referendum and vote on the Accession Treaty. It also calls on Member States to conclude the ratification process quickly. I supported this report. Croatia has met its commitments. However, the Croatian Government needs to resolve the challenges which persist, such as those posed by the judicial system and the continuing battle against corruption and organised crime. Structural reforms also need to be made in the economy, and competitiveness must be stimulated.

 
  
 		 

  Philippe Juvin (PPE), in writing. – (FR) This report welcomes the conclusion of accession negotiations with Croatia. It also supports the country’s spirit of reform and calls on all players across the political, economic, social and cultural spectrum to embrace it. I voted in favour of this report.

 
  
 		 

  Giovanni La Via (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The adoption of this report brings an end to a journey that began six years ago and is hugely significant for both Croatia and the European Union. The enlargement of the EU to include Croatia represents an opportunity for growth and development for both parties to the agreement. This is an important moment and one that concludes years of negotiations that have seen Croatia striving to build social and economic standards in line with the EU’s expectations and principles. It must not be forgotten that the political history of Croatia, as well as many other countries in the Balkans, reflects a difficult and complex path of building democracy. I am sure that today, a new journey has begun which will see, on the one hand, Croatia committed to improving its social sectors and, on the other, the European Union strengthened by enlargement incorporating a new Member State, according to the principles set out by our founding fathers in the awareness of the importance of being united in diversity.

 
  
 		 

  Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE), in writing. – (RO) I voted in favour of Croatia’s accession to the EU. As a representative of a country featuring among the most recent Member States to have joined the European Union, I am pleased that yet another country is going to join the EU in 2013. Croatia’s accession offers a beginning and a model for all the countries in the Western Balkans. The European integration of the Western Balkans is a key strategy for achieving the European objectives of stability and prosperity. Croatia has made progress in every area involved in the accession process during the last 12 months and is a state offering great potential for the EU. The accession process has made a considerable contribution to turning Croatia into a democracy based on European values and has given impetus to the political and economic reforms. All these efforts from the Croatian State must be rewarded so that its citizens can enjoy fully their country’s status as an EU Member State.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I voted for the amendment expressing concerns about the treatment of people who took part in a LGBT pride march in Split on 11 June 2011.

 
  
 		 

  Mario Mauro (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I am voting in favour of the report by Mr Swoboda. The rapporteur has provided a timely reminder of the positive aspects of Croatia’s accession to the European Union and carefully set out the steps that Croatia will have to take in order to foster its European identity, both in its institutions and in the hearts and minds of its citizens.

 
  
 		 

  Mairead McGuinness (PPE), in writing. – This is a historical moment and I strongly support this report welcoming Croatian accession. I look forward to its expected entry into the EU on 1 July 2013, following the ratification process.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The success of Croatia’s accession will have major implications at European level, boosting the process of European integration, as well as being a symbol of hope for the Balkans. Certainly, its accession to the EU provides a strong incentive for potential candidates for accession in that region to effect the political, legislative and economic reforms necessary, so that Croatia’s neighbouring countries fulfil the obligations inherent in the course of full accession to the EU.

 
  
 		 

  Willy Meyer (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (ES) I did not vote in favour of this report because, although my group has always been in favour of Croatia joining the EU, just as it is of any other country that meets the established requirements, I cannot support the EU’s demand for Croatia to implement reforms that go against the interests of the Croatian people. Throughout the accession process, the EU’s main objective has been to foster a competitive neoliberal economy in Croatia and bring about privatisation in certain key sectors. The focus was on improving conditions to make Croatia more attractive to foreign investors. Thus, the reforms being encouraged by the EU are basically aimed at overhauling the socio-economic system, which will lead to increased social and economic differences in the country. That is why I abstained from voting on this report.

 
  
 		 

  Louis Michel (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) Croatia has been able to rely on the broad support of the other Member States throughout the accession process. Our neighbour has not failed to assert our shared values, which is a key consideration. By joining the EU in 2013, Croatia will strengthen its role and its contribution to the creation of a stable region in South-East Europe. I strongly urge our future 28th Member State to cooperate more with Serbia in judicial matters and in the pursuit of war criminals. Accession should also be an opportunity for Croatia to maintain bilateral relations with the other Balkan countries, thereby reaffirming its central position within that region.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – I voted in favour because I think that Croatia should continue stepping up the reforms, in particular, in the field of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and the integration of refugees. The completion of the accession talks and the start of the ratification of the Accession Treaty must not stop the reforms.

 
  
 		 

  Andreas Mölzer (NI), in writing. – (DE) Croatia’s application for membership of the European Union is very much to be welcomed. Having always worked to fulfil the tasks assigned by the EU since the start of accession negotiations, Croatia will be a reliable partner at European level. For this reason, we should welcome the closer integration of the Croatian people, who have always belonged to Europe in cultural terms. Unlike other accession candidates, such as Turkey for example, there is no doubt in relation to Croatia that accession is a logical step in European integration once all the criteria are met – provided that this is the wish of the Croatian people. For this reason, I have voted in favour of Croatia’s application for membership of the European Union.

 
  
 		 

  Radvilė Morkūnaitė-Mikulėnienė (PPE), in writing. – (LT) The example of Croatia again shows that integration into the EU is one of the most effective methods of economic, political and even social change. EU enlargement requires much effort and commitment but is a mutually beneficial instrument which ensures peace, stability, reconciliation and development, and this effect is not confined to one country but also has a regional impact. I hope that Croatia’s success will encourage the other states in the region to go energetically down this path. Even after the Treaty concerning the Accession of the Republic of Croatia has been signed at the European Council on 8-9 December, it will not be a time for relaxation but rather for continuing political and economic reforms, in particular, in the areas of consolidating the rule of law, combating corruption and organised crime, safeguarding human rights, improving the business environment and creating friendly and stable relations with neighbours. The EU must also prepare properly for Croatia’s accession, take account of it in the 2013 multiannual financial framework, and include Croatia in negotiations for the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework. I hope that the ratification process in EU countries will run smoothly and that Croatia will be ready to become the 28th Member State as scheduled from 1 July 2013, during the Lithuanian Council Presidency.

 
  
 		 

  Kristiina Ojuland (ALDE), in writing. – The green light by the European Parliament to the application of Croatia to accede to the EU comes at a very right time. When some external actors may wish to see the EU disintegrating, the accession of a new member sends out a reassuring signal: ‘The reports of its death are greatly exaggerated’. The accession of Croatia does not, however, mark the end of the country’s European integration. The experience of Estonia, as well as of the other Member States that have joined recently, has taught that even more difficult challenges lay ahead. It is far more demanding to establish a relatively small country as a full-fledged active Member State on a routine basis than to meet the fixed criteria and conclude the negotiations. Membership calls for a long-term perspective, patience and willingness to compromise for the common good in order to secure the viability of European Union as an influential global actor. I look forward to working with my future colleagues from Croatia to reach those goals and hope that soon enough, we may greet all the Western Balkans to the European Union.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I welcome this resolution on the accession of Croatia to the European Union. We should welcome the fact that finally, Croatia has successfully reached an historic milestone in the EU integration process. Accession negotiations with Croatia have now been concluded, bringing to an end almost six years of negotiation and several years of preparation. With the political, economic, social and cultural reforms that have been implemented, Croatia has become a solid and mature democracy. It should be borne in mind that accession to the EU should not be regarded as the end of a process but merely a step along the path of ongoing and continuous administrative and economic modernisation.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of this report as I am convinced that the enlargement of the EU is an inherent part of the European project which, with Croatia’s accession, should grow stronger. The conclusion of accession negotiations with Croatia puts an end to almost six years of negotiations and several years of preparation which have changed the socio-political, economic and cultural landscape of the country considerably. Accession to the EU will allow Croatia to maintain the pace of the reforms which it has embarked upon and link it to a project which, given its geographical location, cannot be anything other that its own.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) About eight years ago, Croatia applied to join the European Union. In the meantime, profound changes have taken place in the political situation of that country, leading to Croatia’s transformation into a solid democracy, underpinned by its respect for human rights, which deserves EU policy makers’ applause. Moreover, if we think about the European Union, Croatia’s accession represents the opening up of the Balkans and one more step towards uniting all of Europe politically. In this sense, an incentive for the consolidation of democracies of the different states of the Balkan Peninsula opens up here, with a view to possible accession to the common area. In view of these facts, it is necessary to begin the process of effective entry into the EU. As such, I voted for the resolution and I look forward to the Republic of Croatia’s accession, which represents another step forward in the history of the EU.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. The EP has today given its broad support to Croatian membership, recognising the huge progress made towards reforms by Croatia. The process of reform is not over, however, and Croatia should continue on its reform path. This is particularly true in the areas of justice reform, anti-corruption reforms, minority protection and the prosecution of war crimes. The EP has today also criticised the crackdown on the last Gay Pride Parade in Split, in spite of efforts by the EPP to muzzle this criticism. The EP must now continue to monitor the situation to ensure Croatia implements all reforms and that the EU Commission properly oversees this. To this end, the Greens believe the EP should be given the role of assessing the 6-monthly monitoring reports on Croatia's progress. MEPs also have an important role to convince EU citizens that continuing the enlargement process in the Western Balkans is in the interest of all in Europe.

 
  
 		 

  Licia Ronzulli (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of this document advocating Croatia’s accession to the EU because I think that this country joining the European Union is of strategic importance. However, as pointed out in the document, it is important that the Croatian Government tackles the last remaining queries still pending, particularly in the field of judicial reform and fighting corruption and organised crime.

 
  
 		 

  Tokia Saïfi (PPE), in writing. – (FR) In the last few years, Croatia, which has been in accession negotiations with the European Union since 2005, has implemented radical structural reforms enabling it to meet EU membership requirements. Major reforms have been carried out with a view to promoting job creation, increasing competitiveness and strengthening fiscal policies. Many challenges remain, and the Croatian authorities must continue their reforms, particularly their judicial reforms, to combat corruption and organised crime. In order to heal the wounds of the past, Croatia needs to redouble its efforts to prosecute war criminals, follow the set of recommendations made by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and encourage the return of war refugees, especially the Serbs. Croatia’s forthcoming accession is a positive signal for the region as a whole; it is a sign that reforms pay, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

 
  
 		 

  Nikolaos Salavrakos (EFD), in writing. – (EL) Political enlargement of the EU is one of the most basic parameters of European integration and the enlargement process, as applied by the EU, is also an instrument which provides the facility for constant monitoring of the progress being made by candidate countries, thereby acting as a force for political and economic reform in candidate countries. Enlargement policy is a basic instrument for regional cooperation and for maintaining good neighbourly relations. I wish Croatia every success in its accession endeavour and I trust that it will continue its reform efforts at the same pace.

 
  
 		 

  Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE), in writing. – (PL) During the previous parliamentary term, I had the pleasure of working in the Delegation to the EU-Croatia Joint Parliamentary Committee. The accession of Croatia to the European Union means a strengthening of political stability in the Western Balkans. Let us hope that it is the beginning of the next enlargement of the EU, to include the countries that were formed on the territory of the former Yugoslavia.

I believe that Croatia has fulfilled the necessary economic and political criteria. This was undoubtedly very difficult, considering the situation in which the region finds itself, as new relations are currently forming during a period of crisis. The country would do well to keep up the rate of change, introduce the rule of law, fight corruption and prepare for the challenges of the common market. Welcome and good luck!

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of Croatia joining the European Union. As we wait for Croatian citizens to have their say in a referendum, the EU has given an initial green light to a Union of 28 countries. In the run-up to 1 July 2013, Croatia must continue to resolve its domestic problems, first and foremost fighting corruption and undertaking legal reforms. Structural reforms are needed to keep public debt under control and improve the labour market. So far, Croatia has complied with all the limits that were imposed, even in spite of the ongoing global economic crisis. This is, without doubt, a good sign which gives some hope that this Balkan country will be able to join the EU successfully.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Croatia’s accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013 will be the culmination of eight years of negotiations that deserve full recognition in view of Croatia’s transformation into a solid and mature democracy based on the integral values of the EU. This accession will act as a catalyst for the processes of reform in the Western Balkans. This event will allow Croatia and its citizens to enjoy the rights and guarantees enshrined in the EU Treaties. Along with their rights, the authorities must meet the commitments made during the negotiations and foster the participation of the representatives of civil society throughout the accession procedure. Alongside this, additional support through the Instrument of Pre-Accession Assistance should carry on and adapt to the efforts being made towards reform.

I am voting for this report and would stress that it is still necessary to continue with policies for the reform of the judicial system, so that it is impartial and transparent, for the fight against corruption and cross-border organised crime, and cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, especially through the prosecution of war crimes and the integration of refugees and displaced persons.
