  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted in favour of the report on Croatia’s application to become a member of the European Union because enlarging the EU through Croatia’s accession will help strengthen stability, freedom and prosperity in Europe. One of the EU’s objectives is to strengthen solidarity among its various peoples while respecting their history, culture and traditions. Croatia’s accession requires respect for the values on which the EU is based, as well as for the commitment to promote them. I welcome Croatia’s declaration on promoting European values in South-East Europe. The negotiations were completed on 30 June 2011, the provisions for which were agreed as being fair and appropriate. Consequently, Croatia fulfils the political criteria and we expect it to be ready to join on 1 July 2013. Croatia must continue the economic structural reforms, stimulate employment by revitalising the labour market and continue with fiscal consolidation to stimulate competitiveness. It is important that economic recovery is accompanied by environmental modernisation, including through improving energy efficiency, reinforcing policies on renewable energy sources and harmonising spatial development and energy policies. I urge Croatia to continue to strengthen the rights of workers and trade unions and to enhance social dialogue as part of the decision-making process.

 
  
 		 

  Derek Vaughan (S&D), in writing. – I voted in favour of this report in support of Croatia’s accession to the EU and I look forward to the signature of the Accession Treaty. During negotiations Croatia has worked hard to reform its judicial system, but there remains a need to ensure that progress continues to be made especially on issues such as anti-corruption and minority protection. It is vital that the European Parliament continues to monitor the pre-accession process and is kept informed by the European Commission of the steps taken by Croatia to honour the negotiation commitments.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) The European Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the accession negotiations with Croatia, while also calling on the Republic to continue the initiated reforms with the same level of commitment – specifically in the areas of justice, cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and anti-discrimination policy. I voted in favour.

 
  
  

Report: Carlo Casini (A7-0386/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for this report as I support all measures that help to increase the credibility of politics and, in particular, to increase transparency and confidence in Parliament.

 
  
 		 

  Sophie Auconie (PPE), in writing. – (FR) Since I am in favour of MEPs’ activities becoming more transparent, I voted in favour of Carlo Casini’s report. This Code of Conduct aims to make MEPs more accountable by requiring them to declare the professional activities they undertake alongside their parliamentary duties as well as those they carried out before they took office. It also contains provisions relating to their parliamentary remuneration and all outside remuneration as well as penalties for violations of the Code.

 
  
 		 

  Regina Bastos (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Parliament has approved changes relating to the Code of Conduct of its Members. These amendments aim to strengthen transparency in the fulfilment of their mandate and free vote. The Code of Conduct also provides for penalties in cases of a breach of the established rules that go as far as suspension or removal of their mandate in Parliament. The principles which should govern and guide the behaviour of those elected to Parliament are those of ethical and moral responsibility, as well as strict adherence to the mission of honourable representation that citizens confer upon them. I voted for this report for these reasons.

 
  
 		 

  Jean-Luc Bennahmias (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) We all remember the scandal of the MEPs who ‘sold’ amendments to false lobbyists who were, in fact, journalists. Although this case, which illustrates the general climate of suspicion towards the political class, only involved a tiny minority of MEPs, it sowed doubt about Members’ integrity. By establishing strict rules governing the declaration of financial interests and the prevention of conflicts of interest, the Code of Conduct aims to improve transparency and therefore, so I hope, the image of MEPs in the eyes of the outside world. MEPs will have to declare the professional activities they undertake alongside their parliamentary duties as well as those they carried out before they took office, and rapporteurs may see themselves relieved of that role if a conflict of interest is brought to light. The point of the Code of Conduct is to restore accountability. It is about ensuring that cases like this, which harm everyone, do not happen again in the future.

 
  
 		 

  Mara Bizzotto (EFD), in writing. – (IT) The report sets out a series of laudable amendments to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament. The importance of our roles here means that we are duty-bound, both politically and in terms of ethics and transparency, to make the rules governing the relationship between our positions and our outside interests as stringent and rigorous as possible. I support the insertion of these amendments as per the report by Mr Casini, especially the introduction of greater clarity on conflicts of interest and the funding and support received for carrying out our political activities. The new provisions on penalties for breaching the code and the creation of an Advisory Committee on the behaviour of MEPs are also to be welcomed. My vote on the report by Mr Casini is therefore in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Edite Estrela (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I voted for this report on the amendments to the Rules of Procedure relating to a Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest, as it introduces rigorous amendments to the Code of Conduct, which should contribute towards greater transparency and confidence in Parliament.

 
  
 		 

  Diogo Feio (PPE), in writing. – (PT) It is very important that Members of Parliament fulfil their mandates in fully independent and absolutely transparent conditions. It is, therefore, necessary to welcome the adoption of a Code of Conduct that aims to safeguard independence, transparency and avoid conflicts of interest, similar to what is happening in numerous other areas of activity, especially in other professions that have their own codes of ethics that impose a healthy self-regulation.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The report in question, drafted by Mr Casini, deals with the amendments to Parliament’s Rules of Procedure relating to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest. The current economic crisis, which many citizens attribute to politicians’ wrong decisions, has led to this group of professionals being put under very tight public surveillance involving new information technology, as in the case of Wikileaks, with the disclosure of confidential information. Today, more than ever before, it is crucial that rules for transparency are established with respect to the financial interests of public officials. In the case of Members of the European Parliament, under the terms of Article 232 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, it is up to Parliament to establish rules on the interests of its Members. As I am aware that appearances are extremely important, I am voting for the proposed amendments to the existing regulation.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) Broadly speaking, the report considers that the new Code of Conduct will increase the transparency needed for elected Members of the European Parliament (EP) to perform their duties. The Members of the EP will have to submit a declaration of financial interests containing a range of information including, inter alia, their employment history for the three-year period before taking office with the EP. This report follows some scandals involving Members of the current legislative term, some of whom have since resigned, hence the concerns that are now being mentioned here.

Naturally, we agree with the ban on accepting or receiving ‘any direct or indirect financial benefit or other reward in exchange for influencing, or voting on, legislation, motions for a resolution, written declarations or questions tabled in Parliament or any of its committees’. The Code of Conduct stipulates that Members cannot enter into ‘any agreement to act or vote in the interest of any other legal or natural that would compromise their freedom of vote’. Its effectiveness will need to be assessed and monitored.

 
  
 		 

  Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) The report states that the new Code of Conduct aims to increase transparency. Members of the European Parliament (EP) will have to submit a declaration of financial interests containing a range of information including, inter alia, their employment history for the three-year period before taking up office with the EP, and their membership during that period of any boards or committees of companies, etc. Any occasional remunerated outside activity, including writing, lecturing or the provision of expert advice, must also be declared if the total remuneration exceeds EUR 5 000 in a calendar year.

We know that this report appeared following some scandals involving certain Members that have already left Parliament, hence the concerns that are now being mentioned here. For example, the Code of Conduct stipulates that Members cannot enter into ‘any agreement to act or vote in the interest of any other legal or natural that would compromise their freedom of vote’ or ‘accept or receive any direct or indirect financial benefit or other reward in exchange for influencing, or voting on, legislation, motions for a resolution, written declarations or questions tabled in Parliament or any of its committees’. We shall see how effective it is.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) The changes to the Rules of Procedure will introduce new, clearer and more precise rules and a stricter sanctions regime, which should increase confidence in the European Parliament, and contribute to transparency in EU institutions. The changes to the rules will come mainly in the following areas: the introduction of stricter rules and greater transparency in an effort to prevent conflicts of interest, clear rules regarding the financial statements that will be available on the website of the European Parliament, and stricter rules on donations and similar benefits. The possibility of removing the mandate of a rapporteur in the event of a serious violation of the Code of Conduct is also significant.

 
  
 		 

  Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D), in writing. – (PL) I would like to express my full support for the contents of the new Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest. I am glad that we managed to reach a compromise during work in the relevant committee, as reflected by the large number of votes cast by my fellow Members in favour of amending the Rules of Procedure. New changes to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament represent yet another important step towards introducing clearer rules and, at the same time, clear sanctions for a failure to comply with these rules, and they aim to increase confidence in Parliament as well as making the work of the European institutions more transparent overall.

The new rules focus on introducing rigorous provisions in relation to the problem of conflicts of interest, the preparation of financial statements published on Parliament’s website and the acceptance of special gifts. Moreover, the new provisions also cover rapporteurs, who may lose their mandate if they violate the abovementioned rules contained in the Code of Conduct. I think that the creation of an Advisory Committee on the Conduct of Members is also a good initiative, which will assist Members in the practical interpretation and implementation of the rules of the code. I would once again like to thank the rapporteur from the Committee on Constitutional Affairs for the huge amount of work he has put into preparing the report.

 
  
 		 

  Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of establishing this new Code of Conduct for MEPs. The code forbids Members from undertaking lobbying activities alongside their parliamentary duties, prohibits us from receiving gifts worth more than EUR 150, requires us to notify all the activities that we carry out and remuneration that we receive whilst we are MEPs and before we take office, and requires us to declare any membership of an association, any type of interest in a company or organisation of so-called ‘influence’ and any other type of financial interest. In particular, I voted in favour of Amendment 10, which proposed abolishing the EUR 5 000 threshold above which MEPs must declare all outside activities for which they receive payment. By establishing these strict rules, our Parliament intends to make its daily activities clearer and more transparent. Equally, this is about restoring, to some extent, the external image of MEPs and about combating the prevailing anti-parliamentarism. This code is also intended to re-establish everyone’s accountability. I regret, however, that such measures are only adopted in response to scandals (one recalls here the scandal of the three MEPs caught acting in a blatantly corrupt manner by lobbyists in March 2011).

 
  
 		 

  Sylvie Guillaume (S&D), in writing. – (FR) I supported the creation of an enhanced Code of Conduct for MEPs in order to provide a clear signal regarding my demands for elected officials to act transparently and to abide by a number of ethical rules. Accordingly, I consider it essential to prevent Members from undertaking an additional professional activity involving lobbying activities that could have an improper influence on the performance of their duties. Further, in order to rule out any possible abuse, provision must be made for penalties, which are proposed in this Code of Conduct. Finally, I rejected the initiatives aimed at weakening this set of measures – which some felt were ‘too transparent’ – as they would have prevented us from achieving an objective: that of restoring citizens’ faith in their elected officials.

 
  
 		 

  Marian Harkin (ALDE), in writing. – I support this report as it goes a long way towards putting in place a Code of Conduct for MEPs in regard to financial interests and conflicts of interest. It is important that we carry out work in the most transparent way and, indeed, in an accountable fashion. However, I supported the amendment which proposed that we declare any remunerated income, not only that above EUR 5 000. I know there are administrative issues but this figure is far too high. For some people in some Member States, EUR 5 000 represents a year’s income and regardless of where you live, it is a very significant sum of money. I am concerned that we are giving out the wrong message here, and much of the good work we do will have been cancelled out by leaving this EUR 5 000 figure as part of the Code of Conduct – it is just too high.

 
  
 		 

  Juozas Imbrasas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I welcomed the amendments to the Rules of Procedure introducing a requirement to declare any other paid activity and income. It is my conviction that, in exercising their duties, Members of the European Parliament should be guided by and observe the following general principles of conduct: unselfishness, integrity, openness, diligence, honesty, accountability and respect for Parliament’s reputation. They should therefore act solely in the public interest and refrain from obtaining or seeking to obtain any direct or indirect financial benefit or other reward.

 
  
 		 

  Petru Constantin Luhan (PPE), in writing. – (RO) I welcome the adoption of the Code of Conduct for MEPs as there was a great need for such a code. The Code of Conduct defines conflicts of interest and envisages the option to sanction MEPs, including by suspension or removal from office. The code clearly indicates that MEPs cannot accept money or benefits in exchange for votes or legislative or political activities within the European Parliament. In addition, according to the new code, MEPs must submit a declaration of financial interests which specifies some of the following details: - professional activities from the last three years prior to taking up office in Parliament; - any regular remunerated activity carried out as an MEP, alongside the exercise of their office; - any occasional remunerated outside activity (including writing, lecturing or the provision of expert advice) if the total remuneration exceeds EUR 5 000 in a calendar year; - any gift or benefit valued at more than EUR 150, received by an MEP when carrying out his or her duties, must be refused or, if officially representing Parliament, be transferred to the European Parliament.

 
  
 		 

  Monica Luisa Macovei (PPE), in writing. – I voted in favour of this first Code of Conduct for MEPs. The code defines the conflict of interest, requires the disclosure of activities during the three years prior to the MEP’s mandate, and foresees the possibility to apply penalties, including the suspension or removal of the MEP from office. The code is a first step towards transparency and the prevailing of public interest. The code shows clearly that MEPs cannot receive money or favours in exchange for their vote or their legislative or political activity with the European Parliament. We should go further and prohibit paid membership of boards of directors, as well as a second paid job, except teaching and similar work clearly defined.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I am delighted that the European Parliament has adopted a code of conduct which compares with the best practice in any of our national parliaments.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Recent events involving certain Members of the European Parliament, which led to the resignation of a number of them, have forced Parliament to adopt some changes to the Code of Conduct of its Members. They are seeking to increase transparency in the performance of their duties and in their freedom of vote. These changes also provide for penalties in the event of non-compliance with the rules that have been laid down, which could result in the suspension or removal of a Member. There are certain principles that must be upheld in the conduct of those elected to Parliament when performing the duties for which they were elected by the people of their respective countries: these are to fulfil an ethical and moral responsibility and to scrupulously carry out the mandate granted by the electorate, which is to represent the people honourably. That is why I voted as I did.

 
  
 		 

  Willy Meyer (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (ES) I voted in favour of this report because it represents progress in the fight against nepotism and corruption in Parliament. We must learn from our mistakes and make sure the regulation is reviewed in two years’ time. The new regulation contains stricter rules on donations and declarations of interests and income, but we must continue to call for even stricter standards.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – Amendments are aimed at making the financial side of MEPs’ work become more clear and transparent.

 
  
 		 

  Radvilė Morkūnaitė-Mikulėnienė (PPE), in writing. – (LT) Although the European Parliament has become a fully-fledged legislative institution under the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular, as regards establishing the EU budget, the media and voters probably talk more about our salaries, benefits and related scandals than about the work we do. It is also a fact that Members of the European Parliament are able to obtain any amount of remuneration or other income from other sources without having to declare or report it to anybody. MEPs’ salaries are several or even many times greater than those of many of their constituents, so that when we talk about reducing poverty in Europe one day and then oppose a requirement to declare additional income the next, we look hypocritical. I welcome the amendments to the Rules of Procedure introducing a requirement to declare any other paid activity and income. It is nevertheless important that these provisions are actually implemented and do not remain merely aspirational. On the other hand, I believe that we could go even further by prohibiting MEPs from receiving any additional remuneration, as is done in some Member States’ national parliaments. Surely we will not become impoverished by living solely from our salary?

 
  
 		 

  Franz Obermayr (NI), in writing. – (DE) The present crisis of confidence underlines the need for a clear code of conduct for Members of the European Parliament in relation to financial interests and possible conflicts of interest. Every MEP should perform his or her duties in accordance with the fundamental principles of impartiality, integrity, openness, due diligence, honesty, responsibility and maintaining Parliament’s good name. When a conflict of interest arises, the provisions of this code of conduct should provide some guidance. If the MEP is unable to resolve the conflict of interest, he is obliged to inform the President in writing. In cases of doubt, confidential advice can be sought from the Advisory Committee on the Conduct of Members. In addition, before speaking or voting in plenary or at any of Parliament’s institutions, or when proposed as rapporteur, every Member should disclose any existing or potential conflict of interest in relation to the matter under consideration. Such a disclosure can be made orally or in writing to the President during the relevant parliamentary debates. I believe that these measures make sense and will promote confidence. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

 
  
 		 

  Siiri Oviir (ALDE), in writing. – (ET) I consider it important to change the European Parliament’s Rules of Procedure, which would, among other things, create a better overview of Members’ paid extra-parliamentary activities and the income connected therewith. Although I support Mr Casini’s report, I do not support sub-clause ‘e’ of the motion to amend clause 2 number 10, which would require Members of Parliament to declare in their declarations of economic interests only those extra-parliamentary expenses above EUR 5 000 per calendar year. I find that the establishment of such a limit is not justified because it would encourage the non-declaration of income that falls just short of the EUR 5 000 limit. In addition, it is unclear why EUR 5 000 should be chosen as the limit; why not EUR 2 000 or 200, for instance? EUR 5 000 is a large amount of money – in many Member States, it represents the annual pay of a worker who earns average wages. I believe that in the interests of greater transparency, Members of the European Parliament should declare all income received from extra-parliamentary activities, and if we are to set a limit, it could be 10 times lower, for instance, EUR 500.

 
  
 		 

  Alfredo Pallone (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Clarity and transparency are at the heart of the work of all MEPs, since we are the direct representatives of our citizens’ interests. All of us, from our lofty positions, must set an example and not fall prey to compromises that contradict the goals of our mandates. The report by Mr Casini amends the regulation on the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament, adding yet further details, in the hope that nobody can fall foul any longer of financial irregularities and conflicts of interest. My vote in favour is tantamount to a personal promise to the electorate of clarity and transparency.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted for the change to the Rules of Procedure regarding the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament in respect of financial interests and conflicts of interest because I believe that it is a good draft overall. However, I believe that it could, and should, have gone further on certain points so as to increase transparency, not least as regards the salaries of Members, which should be made public without exception. That is what I have advocated and continue to advocate along with other fellow Members who have also been defeated in this battle.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest aims to equip the EU’s legal system with instruments that will ensure transparency in decision-making procedures, so as to prevent situations of abuse of power. However, in order for these rules to come into effect, the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament must be amended. That is the aim of the current proposal, which is why I voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Frédérique Ries (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) The Code of Conduct for MEPs adopted this afternoon responds to the need for our day-to-day work in the European Parliament to become clearer and more transparent. Equally, it responds to the recent scandals caused by a few MEPs who were paid to defend particular interests, unspeakable behaviour that was immediately denounced by the Presidency of Parliament and the national and European parties who rushed to exclude these black sheep. The new rules include greater transparency and control over Members’ declarations of financial interests, a clear definition of the meaning of conflict of interest, the obligation to refuse any gift worth more than EUR 150 and the establishment of a committee in which Members are monitored by their peers. Be that as it may, and to quote a colleague who has a way with words: ‘Catching someone with their hand in the cookie jar is no reason to ban cookies …’ Even with the strictest possible rules and penalties, you will not prevent abuse. Integrity is not decreed, it is applied, and it relies, above all, upon moral duty, personal ethics and a sense of responsibility, all values that do not bear compromise.

 
  
 		 

  Robert Rochefort (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) In any democratic society, citizens have the right to demand honest and responsible behaviour from their leaders. The legitimacy of power is at stake, and we cannot permit scandals involving a small number of politicians to affect the reputation of all decision makers. All conflicts of interest should therefore be avoided, and transparency must be the order of the day. Accordingly, all relevant information relating to the professional lives of Members should be made available to the public. In this respect, I welcome the vote on Carlo Casini’s report. The text aims, in fact, to make entirely worthy changes to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest: a reminder of the general principles of conduct – disinterest, integrity, openness, diligence, honesty, accountability and respect for Parliament’s reputation; the ability to suspend a Member from all of his or her duties or as rapporteur for a committee; the declaration of all offices that could influence parliamentary work and/or that are remunerated; the publication of financial support and support in terms of staff; and the supervision of courtesy gifts.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour, although I also supported the request to eliminate the EUR 5 000 threshold for declaring occasional remunerated activity. In my view, we have to declare everything, not only the income above EUR 5 000.

 
  
 		 

  Licia Ronzulli (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of this document because I believe that this code sets out rules and principles that MEPs ought to respect in their external dealings so as to avoid any conflicts of interest. The new Code of Conduct will offer a robust shield against unethical actions and is a big step forward in comparison to the current situation. The broad consensus shown by my fellow Members on the new Code of Conduct has a symbolic value that cannot be ignored. Externally, it shows the public that Parliament is a transparent mechanism working for the common good and for building Europe on the foundations of freedom and justice.

 
  
 		 

  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the European Parliament decision amending the Rules of Procedure regarding the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament in respect of financial interests and conflicts of interest, as I think that Parliament needs to have clear regulations on transparency with regard to financial interests and the conduct of its members. The Rules of Procedure set out guidelines on how MEPs should exercise their office. In exercising their office, MEPs act only in the general interest without obtaining or trying to obtain any direct or indirect financial benefit or any other benefit. At the same time, MEPs are guided by and observe the following general principles of conduct: disinterest, integrity, transparency, diligence, honesty, accountability and respect for Parliament’s reputation. Parliament drafts rules on transparency with regard to the financial interests of its members in the form of a code of conduct, adopted by the majority of members who comprise it, in accordance with Article 232 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which will be appended to the Rules of Procedure. The Bureau adopts implementing measures for this Code of Conduct, including a monitoring procedure, and may submit proposals for revision of the Code of Conduct.

 
  
 		 

  Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (FR) I voted for this report, which clarifies and strengthens control over the money received by MEPs and what they do with it. This report is far from being the most fundamentally political of reports. It does, however, serve as a response to those who are attempting, once again, to win votes on the dangerous ground of anti-parliamentarism. To those people, who include certain members of the far right, we say: ‘There should be nothing to hide!’ Incidentally, I regret that the members of the Confederal Group of the European United Left – Nordic Green Left were the only ones who all voted against an amendment proposing to limit the declaration of supplementary income to income in excess of EUR 5 000. Unfortunately, this amendment was still adopted. Let us hope that this text will help put an end to numerous fantasies that discredit political action as a whole and that are constantly fed by the practices, inherent in human nature, of a few. Following this further step in the direction of greater transparency, political debate should refocus on far more important issues.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) This report deals with a number of amendments to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament in relation to financial interests and possible conflicts of interest in exercising their mandate. In line with the principle of transparency, in future, MEPs are to disclose their professional activities for the three years preceding their mandate, listing income – including non-regular income – and professional positions. I voted in favour.

 
  
  

Report: Bernhard Rapkay (A7-0411/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for this report because the rapporteur argues cogently that the immunity of Mr Uspaskich cannot be defended.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Following the criminal proceedings brought against a Member of this House, Mr Uspaskich, and pending before Vilnius Regional Court (Lithuania), Parliament decided on 7 September 2010 to waive his parliamentary immunity. Mr Uspaskich was unhappy with this decision and submitted two appeals. The first was submitted on 5 April 2011 and was announced in Parliament in the plenary session of 9 May 2011. The second was submitted on 11 April 2011 and was announced in Parliament in the plenary session of 4 July 2011. Since the two requests were related to the same matter, Parliament decided that they should be dealt with together. This report concerns Mr Uspaskich’s appeal of 5 April 2011 for Parliament to accede to his request to defend his immunity, in accordance with Article 7 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. Given that the incidents took place before he was elected to Parliament, and in view of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I am voting for Parliament’s decision not to defend Mr Uspaskich’s parliamentary immunity and privileges.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Benová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) It is appropriate to deal with the requests made by Viktor Uspaskich on 5 and 11 April 2011 together since they relate to the same legal proceedings. Criminal proceedings have been brought against the Member of the European Parliament (MEP), who is charged essentially with offences of false accounting in relation to the financing of a political party during a period prior to his election to the European Parliament. On 7 September 2010, Parliament waived Viktor Uspaskich’s immunity, considering that no cogent evidence had been furnished as to the existence of any fumus persecutionis and that the offences with which the MEP is charged had nothing to do with his activities as a Member of the European Parliament. Subsequently, on 28 October 2010, Viktor Uspaskich brought an action for the annulment of Parliament’s decision of 7 September 2010 before the General Court, only to withdraw it in July 2011. In a letter of 5 April 2011 requesting the defence of his immunity, he claims that the criminal proceedings initiated by the Lithuanian authorities prevent him from performing, or make it difficult for him to perform, his parliamentary duties by restraining his freedom of movement contrary to Article 7 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. After thoroughly examining all of the available facts, however, Parliament has concluded not to defend the immunity and privileges of Viktor Uspaskich and will forward this decision and the report of its competent committee to the appropriate authority in the Republic of Lithuania.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I followed the recommendation of the rapporteur in the case of Mr Viktor Uspaskich.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. – (PT) It is Parliament’s responsibility to defend the independence of its Members’ mandates and that independence cannot be jeopardised. The Member of the European Parliament, Mr Uspaskich, is facing charges of offences of what is essentially false accounting in relation to the financing of a political party during a period prior to his election to the European Parliament. On 7 September 2010, Parliament waived the parliamentary immunity of Mr Uspaskich because it believed no convincing evidence had been given for his allegation of fumus persecutionis and that the criminal activities of which Mr Uspaskich is accused are unrelated to his activities as a Member of this House. That is why I am voting in favour of not waiving the parliamentary immunity and privileges of Mr Uspaskich.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – I abstained from voting because the case is entirely political and not all aspects and documents of this case were carefully examined.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. The JURI Committee has decided that Uspaskich’s claim should be rejected on the grounds that no sufficient nexus has been established between the alleged new facts and the bringing of proceedings against Uspaskich for false accounting.

 
  
  

Report: Bernhard Rapkay (A7-0413/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for this report because the rapporteur argues cogently that the immunity of Mr Uspaskich cannot be defended.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Following the criminal proceedings brought against a Member of this House, Mr Uspaskich, and pending before Vilnius Regional Court (Lithuania), Parliament decided on 7 September 2010 to waive his parliamentary immunity. Mr Uspaskich was unhappy with this decision and submitted two appeals. The first was submitted on 5 April 2011 and was announced in Parliament in the plenary session of 9 May 2011. The second was submitted on 11 April 2011 and was announced in Parliament in the plenary session of 4 July 2011. Since the two requests were related to the same matter, Parliament decided that they should be dealt with together. This report concerns Mr Uspaskich’s request to Parliament of 11 April 2011 to review the decision it made in the plenary session of 7 September 2010 to waive his parliamentary immunity. In view of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I am voting for Parliament’s decision not to defend the parliamentary immunity and privileges of Mr Uspaskich, given that the incidents took place before he was elected to Parliament and are unrelated to his duties as a Member of this House.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Benová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) It is appropriate to deal with the requests made by Viktor Uspaskich on 5 and 11 April 2011 together since they relate to the same legal proceedings. Criminal proceedings have been brought against the Member of the European Parliament (MEP), who is charged essentially with offences of false accounting in relation to the financing of a political party during a period prior to his election to the European Parliament. On 7 September 2010 Parliament waived Viktor Uspaskich’s immunity, considering that no cogent evidence had been furnished as to the existence of any fumus persecutionis and that the offences with which the MEP is charged had nothing to do with his activities as a Member of the European Parliament. Subsequently, on 28 October 2010, Viktor Uspaskich brought an action for the annulment of Parliament’s decision of 7 September 2010 before the General Court, only to withdraw it in July 2011. In a letter of 5 April 2011 requesting the defence of his immunity, he claims that the criminal proceedings initiated by the Lithuanian authorities prevent him from performing, or make it difficult for him to perform, his parliamentary duties by restraining his freedom of movement contrary to Article 7 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. After thoroughly examining all of the available facts, however, Parliament has concluded not to defend the immunity and privileges of Viktor Uspaskich and will forward this decision and the report of its competent committee to the appropriate authority in the Republic of Lithuania.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I voted to waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – I abstained from voting because the case is entirely political and not all aspects and documents of this case were carefully examined.

 
  
 		 

  Siiri Oviir (ALDE), in writing. – (ET) Unlike the other members of my group, I did not vote in favour of this report, which did not support the request by the Member of the European Parliament, Mr Viktor Uspaskich, who was elected from Lithuania, for a review of the European Parliament decision of 7 September 2010 regarding him. Through WikiLeaks, my earlier suspicion that the accusations made against Mr Uspaskich were politically motivated, and that procedure was violated in his case, were once again confirmed. Many Lithuanian politicians, including members of the governing party, have admitted that several procedural rules were violated, and that the accusations do not necessarily have any legal basis, but the withdrawal of the accusations made against Mr Uspaskich would tarnish the reputation of Lithuania’s governmental institutions and legal system. All of this reminds me of a series of earlier cases connected with members of my home party, the Estonian Centre Party, where it became clear after the elections that the accusations had been politically motivated and unfounded. In this case, protecting the reputation of the Lithuanian government agencies and legal system is not my concern, but the defence of justice and human rights is. These are among the axioms of the European Union considered to be of the utmost importance.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The European Parliament has been asked to waive the parliamentary immunity of a Member of this House, Mr Uspaskich. The Committee on Legal Affairs has issued its opinion on the matter, with a report that decided to waive his parliamentary immunity being adopted unanimously. Indeed, it was thought that no basis had been found for the allegation of fumus persecutionis in the case at hand.

 
  
  

Reports: Bernhard Rapkay (A7-0411/2011 and A7-0413/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. The JURI Committee has decided that Uspaskich’s claim should be rejected on the grounds that no sufficient nexus has been established between the alleged new facts and the bringing of proceedings against Uspaskich for false accounting.

 
  
  

Report: Pervenche Berès (A7-0384/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for this report because the rapporteur has tabled at least two important proposals: to reinforce Parliament’s role in the codecision process as regards the European Semester and to step up cooperation between Parliament and national parliaments.

 
  
 		 

  Roberta Angelilli (PPE), in writing. – (IT) We find ourselves in a specific moment of crisis in which the coordination of Member States’ economic policies has a crucial role. The experience of the preceding European Semester has shown that national reform programmes still lack transparency and viability. National economic and budgetary policies must be used to reach the objectives set out in the Stability Pact and the Europe 2020 strategy. That is why we need to assess the situation at a European level, so that the Union can take a coordinated approach in order to tackle European and national economic difficulties. I hope that in January, starting with the presentation of the Annual Growth Survey by the Commission, a clearer framework of all the future coordination actions in the economic sphere is mapped out for us, so that the challenges ahead can be faced with greater determination and fortitude.

 
  
 		 

  Sophie Auconie (PPE), in writing. – (FR) The European Parliament demonstrated resolve and ambition in dealing with the economic and financial crisis when, last September, it adopted the ‘economic governance package’, which contains six legislative proposals all designed to strengthen economic governance in the European Union. One of these proposals includes the establishment of a European Semester, a forum for debate in which to assess and coordinate the economic and budgetary policies of Member States before they go ahead and adopt them. Although I am convinced that this coordination is essential in order to pull Europe out of the crisis, I note that the Berès report does not really heed the lessons of the first European Semester, trialled last July.

 
  
 		 

  Margrete Auken and Emilie Turunen (Verts/ALE), in writing. – (DA) Paragraph 63 of the Berès report on the European Semester calls for ‘the development of the concept of a European Treasury to strengthen the implementation capacity of the European Semester and the economic pillar of EMU’. However, it is not explained in any more detail in the report what this concept of a European Treasury would cover. The members of the Danish Socialist People’s Party in the European Parliament therefore have reservations about this passage, but have voted in favour of the report in general, as it contains many good elements.

 
  
 		 

  Jean-Luc Bennahmias (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) The Berès report is commendable in that it rebalances the Commission’s proposal on the European Semester, which simply had to be done. By focusing on the priority of employment and on the idea that the budgetary, economic and social strategies introduced must have a redistributive and developmental role, the report gives new meaning to the prospects of overcoming the crisis, as we hope to do. Unfortunately, the European Parliament is still not involved enough in the European Semester process, just as, in fact, it is often excluded from the current crisis management efforts, which is a key problem for EU democracy and legitimacy. Therefore, I can only share the view that an interparliamentary conference involving both the EP and the national parliaments should be organised next year, so that, finally, we can open a broader debate on the measures we want to take and the project we want to support.

 
  
 		 

  Cristian Silviu Buşoi (ALDE), in writing. – (RO) I support this resolution because I think that coordination of economic policies is particularly important to the euro area’s operation, and this resolution contains a number of very useful recommendations for improving the European Semester. I think that the coordination process needs to have broader democratic legitimacy. For this to happen, the European Parliament and national parliaments need to be more actively involved. I am pleased that the rapporteur abandoned the notion of setting up a special parliamentary committee made up only of MEPs from the countries in the euro area, as such an initiative would have led to a split in Parliament, exerting an adverse impact on its operation. Such a measure is especially difficult to understand as most Member States which are not part of the euro area at the moment, including Romania, would like to adopt the single currency in the future. This means that all the Members of this Parliament have an interest in making the euro area operate efficiently. Last but not least, as is also recommended in this report, I feel it is absolutely essential that Member States’ economic policies attach major importance to economic growth as, in the current climate of austerity, we greatly need policies which will bring us back to the path of economic growth and put an end to austerity.

 
  
 		 

  Maria Da Graça Carvalho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The national parliaments are freely elected and are therefore the representatives and the guarantors of the rights acquired and delegated by the citizens. The introduction of the European Semester should fully respect the prerogatives of national parliaments. I welcome the introduction of the European Semester as an institutional process under the leadership of the EU institutions. I also welcome increased coordination among the Member States for implementing the Europe 2020 strategy, not least its macro-economic dimension.

 
  
 		 

  Nikolaos Chountis (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (EL) The European Semester and closer coordination of fiscal policies between the Member States, based on the prevailing neoliberal approach, is fully in keeping with plans by the Merkel/Sarkozy alliance. On the pretext of ‘regaining’ the trust of the markets, citizens’ rights are being sacrificed and social acquis is being trampled underfoot. Continuous austerity and continuous recession, unemployment and poverty are essentially becoming systemic. The European Semester has been overtaken by events. It no longer suffices to safeguard the interests of Ms Merkel and her allies. However, it is the ‘basic idea’ for creating a stricter stability pact and a ‘fiscal union of the willing’ which will put a stranglehold on the Member States and the European people. The budgets of the Member States will be planned and approved by Berlin, while the creation of a multi-track Europe of the ‘strong’ and the ‘weak’ will leave the weaker Member States prey to the whims of speculators. The report on the European Semester is fully in line with the failed neoliberal policies of the EU and deprives the Member States of the facility to exercise an alternative, anti-cyclical policy designed to redistribute wealth and sustainable growth. It is for all these reasons that I voted against the report.

 
  
 		 

  Lara Comi (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of this report since I believe that coordinating economic policies has an extremely important role to play in this period of major crisis for the European Union. Now more than ever, Europe must take a symmetrical approach, founded on a shared response from the Member States, to the problems deriving from the economic crisis, the resulting increase in inequality and macro-financial imbalances. In my opinion, the various countries’ policies ought to be highly interconnected so as to guarantee sustainable growth and increased employment, as set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. The Union must address European citizens’ lack of faith in European integration. I therefore consider it essential that this coordination is geared towards ensuring greater legitimacy, accountability and transparency in decision-making processes. Furthermore, since the goal of the European Semester is to check that the budget discipline is being applied and to supervise the realisation of the EU 2020 strategy, the requirement for transparency is essential. I am hoping for greater effort from the Member States to ensure that economic, financial and social policies are more effective.

 
  
 		 

  Edite Estrela (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I voted for the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination because it highlights the need to step up the parliamentary dimension of economic governance by introducing the codecision process of the European Semester and strengthening cooperation between the national parliaments and the European Parliament.

 
  
 		 

  Diogo Feio (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Today, the European Semester is fully accepted as a cornerstone of the new economic governance framework. The main purpose of this process, which was set out for the first time in the first economic governance package, is to increase economic and fiscal coordination and to ensure the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy in all Member States. As such, it aims to attribute a greater level of democratic responsibility to national parliaments, in both the preparation and the subsequent implementation of their national budgets, and, at the same time, to offer a platform for the exchange of information and for sharing best budgetary implementation practices. It is undeniable that reinforcing economic coordination policies is one way for Europe to achieve the necessary fiscal consolidation it requires. The economic situation we are currently experiencing has further emphasised this need, and a lot certainly remains to be done in this respect.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This report, drafted by Ms Honeyball, addresses the problem of early school leaving and the measures and instruments adopted by the EU aimed at assisting the Member States in setting out more efficient and effective national policies to resolve this problem. In the Europe 2020 strategy, the six headline targets include the reduction of the proportion of early school leavers to 10%. It should be noted that in 2009, the early school leaving rate for all 18 to 24-year-olds stood at 14.4%. This is a matter of extreme importance, as by tackling this problem, we will not only boost the self-esteem of citizens, but also improve their quality of life, thus helping to reduce poverty and the number of those who are socially excluded. Firstly, it is necessary to identify groups that are at risk, such as ethnic minorities, parents who have a low level of education, children from rural areas, as well as the causes of dropping out of school, such as academic failure and the factors that exacerbate it, including poverty, abuse and an unstable family background. In view of the fact that this problem requires a comprehensive approach and the mobilisation of all those involved in the process of education and teaching, I voted for this report.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) This is yet another crucial report because of the importance of the issues at stake and its profoundly negative implications. Like the other fundamental steps being taken in this process of European integration – which is clearly culminating in the serious economic and social crisis we are facing – this is yet another report that has the support of the Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats) and of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament. This unholy alliance is now trying to impose an ever greater budgetary discipline on the Member States. By making policy coordination an end in itself, it is seeking to gloss over the profoundly negative and reactionary nature of these policies.

Regrettably, the series of amendments we tabled to this report were not adopted, as they were rejected by the unholy alliance. For example, some of the amendments we tabled criticise the veritably aggressive programmes of the troika of the International Monetary Fund, the European Commission and the European Central Bank; defend a policy of effective budgetary stabilisation that takes account of growth and is aimed at wealth redistribution, sustainable development, job creation and social progress; and stress the need to reverse neoliberal economic policies in order to overcome the crisis. That is why we voted against.

 
  
 		 

  Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) Imposing ever-increasing budgetary discipline on the Member States in line with the predominant economic policies will not help us to recover from this crisis or prevent a future crisis from breaking out. Instead, it may exacerbate its effects, increase inequality, poverty and unemployment, and lead to the impoverishment of the people.

We therefore tabled amendments to this report, which have not been adopted. For example, some of the amendments we tabled call on the Member States, the Council and the Commission to take account of the strong and ever-increasing resistance of European citizens to the harsh measures of the troika’s ‘bailout packages’ and the austerity policies followed; consider fiscal policy an important instrument in the management of economic and development policy, but the introduction of the European Semester and the stifling effects arising from the anticipation of fiscal policy coordination will prevent the Member States from having the ability and the flexibility required to pursue an effective stabilisation policy aimed at redistribution of wealth, at sustainable development and at job creation, so providing people with an adequate range of public services and infrastructure; and stress that trying to overcome the crisis by implementing stricter budgetary discipline and deregulation measures will not eliminate the root causes of the crisis but will instead aggravate the situation and reinforce neoliberal economic policies.

Regrettably, all of these have been rejected.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Benová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) The deepening crisis, inequalities and macro-financial imbalances and disparities in competitiveness have highlighted the need for the Union to tackle macro-economic imbalances more appropriately, coordinate economic and fiscal policies more closely, and improve budgetary surveillance. Several interlinked policies for sustainable growth and jobs should form the basis for an improved economic governance framework. Excessive debt and deficits in some Member States can have profound negative spill over effects on other Member States and on the euro area as a whole. I consider it necessary and important to ensure greater interaction between employment, social and economic policies in the context of the European Semester. These steps should be taken for the benefit of all generations and in a manner fostering democratic accountability, ownership and legitimacy of all actors involved. An essential part of this is the support and full involvement of the European Parliament. The European Semester is an institutional process, under the leadership of the European Union (EU) institutions, of increased coordination across Member States for the implementation of the EU strategy, notably in its macro-economic dimension.

 
  
 		 

  Vicky Ford (ECR), in writing. – European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. The ECR Group voted against the report on the basis that Article 121 of the TFEU clearly states that: ‘Member States shall regard their economic policies as a matter of common concern and shall coordinate them within the Council, in accordance with Article 120’. It is therefore against the TFEU for the report to call for a codecision procedure in paragraph 41. We also could not support paragraph 63 which calls for the development of the concept of a European Treasury. For these reasons, we were unable to support the report.

 
  
 		 

  Estelle Grelier (S&D), in writing. – (FR) I voted for Ms Berès’s resolution as it is vitally important for the emergence of European economic governance to go hand in hand with greater democratic scrutiny. In order to deal with the major changes that will have to take place if it is to emerge from the crisis, the EU must ensure the strong democratic legitimacy of its decisions. This legitimacy can only be guaranteed with the European Parliament’s support and involvement in the annual drafting of the EU’s main economic policy guidelines. In particular, it is essential for Parliament to participate in the European Semester procedure, during which each of the 27 draft national budgets is assessed by the European Commission. Following this procedure, Parliament should have the chance to amend the macro-economic policy guidelines proposed to Member States. This democratic development also requires enhanced dialogue with the national parliaments and the social partners in order to support European economic policy coherence and guarantee that the EU 2020 objectives are taken into account. Finally, it is vital that the Treaties be revised only with the agreement and, where necessary, the involvement, of Parliament.

 
  
 		 

  Sylvie Guillaume (S&D), in writing. – (FR) I voted for Ms Berès’s report in order to denounce the current lack of democratic legitimacy regarding the definition of the Union’s economic framework, through the European Semester. The European Parliament and the national parliaments must be able to make their voices heard in this process so as to ensure its credibility. Indeed, a purely intergovernmental system of coordination is an inadequate response to the requirement for economic policies to be regarded as a matter of common concern. We must ensure only the requisite action by the Union in areas governed by the Community method. Lastly, the Annual Growth Survey must also be transformed into ‘Annual Sustainable Growth Guidelines’, aimed at enhancing sustainable growth, subject to a codecision procedure.

 
  
 		 

  Gunnar Hökmark and Anna Ibrisagic (PPE), in writing. – (SV) We Swedish Conservatives and Christian Democrats today voted in favour of an own-initiative report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. The semester constitutes an important framework for increased budgetary discipline in the EU Member States. This report provides recommendations for how the current legislation should be updated, and we agree with most of the proposals. On the other hand, we are opposed to the recommendation to establish a ‘European Treasury’. We also believe that the semester should focus solely on factors that are essential for stable public finances.

 
  
 		 

  Juozas Imbrasas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) The European Semester is an institutional process, under the leadership of the EU institutions, of increased coordination across Member States for the implementation of EU strategy, notably in its macro-economic dimension. The European Semester has two objectives: to verify the application of budgetary discipline by Member States and – at the same time – to monitor the proper delivery of the Europe 2020 strategy by securing the financial means necessary for its implementation. I welcomed the document because the introduction of the European Semester should lead to the increased, well-defined involvement of the European Parliament and national parliaments and to changes in their work. The introduction of the European Semester and enhanced economic and fiscal policy coordination should leave enough scope and flexibility for the EU Member States to pursue an effective budgetary, economic and social strategy, appropriate in accordance with the EU 2020 strategy, geared to distribution and development and providing an adequate level of public services and infrastructure for EU citizens.

 
  
 		 

  Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE), in writing. – (LV) I supported the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination as I believe that stable export markets are in Latvia’s interests. Unfortunately, events in Europe no longer allow us to rely on the stability of these markets. We must therefore ensure that Member States, and the euro area countries in particular, agree on joint liability and put their national finances in order. Many euro area countries must now do as Latvia has successfully done in the last two years.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I voted for this resolution which ‘Views as regrettable the lack of clarity in, and the overlapping of, the different instruments and budgetary lines through which the Europe 2020 targets are to be achieved via the EU budget’ and ‘recalls that the European Semester provides a good opportunity to develop greater synergy between EU and Member State budgets’.

 
  
 		 

  Mario Mauro (PPE), in writing. – (IT) As provided for in the Europe 2020 strategy, the improved economic governance framework should rely on several interlinked policies for sustainable growth and jobs, which need to be coherent with each other in order to provide sustainable growth and jobs. The European Semester offers a useful mechanism through which to put these proposals into action. The Member States in the euro area, which are linked by a shared responsibility, will, without doubt, benefit from it. My vote is in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Arlene McCarthy (S&D), in writing. – Labour MEPs backed this lengthy report as it includes important and positive proposals, including the importance of the European Commission's analysis of growth focusing on long-term sustainable growth. We also welcome its clarification that wages, pensions and other crucial elements of a nation’s social system are issues for subsidiarity which Member States themselves should decide on, without intervention from the European Union. The report makes limited reference to exploring the concept of a European Treasury to support the economic pillar of Economic and Monetary Union. It is a matter for eurozone Members to determine whether such an institution is to be put in place for the eurozone, but Labour MEPs do not support any implication that such bodies should apply to non-eurozone Member States.

 
  
 		 

  Mairead McGuinness (PPE), in writing. – The European Semester involves the monitoring of the Member States’ economic, budgetary and employment policies and the identification of growth-enhancing measures to assist in the achievement of national targets under the EU 2020 strategy. In the context of the current economic crisis, a European Semester that aims to ensure sustained convergence of the economic and fiscal performance of the Member States is to be welcomed. Overcoming the sovereign debt crisis requires a closer coordination of economies, which this report advocates. I voted to support this report.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. – (PT) As the European Semester is a process for coordinating Member States’ economic policies, it is implemented by the European Union to impose budgetary discipline and to ensure compliance with the Europe 2020 strategy. It is very important that the European institutions have adopted new measures aimed at helping the Member States to correct excessive deficits and to achieve greater coordination of their economic and budgetary policies.

 
  
 		 

  Willy Meyer (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (ES) I voted against the European Commission proposal on economic governance and coordination, known as the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination, because it means giving more power to the markets, confirming the commitment to deregulation and giving them – in other words, the oligopolies made up of big multinationals and the financial sector – free rein to do business, filling a few pockets with privatised rights in the name of austerity and cuts. This initiative leaves national parliaments with their hands tied, imposing EU supervision over their budgets to make sure they keep the markets happy at all times, regardless of whether or not the budgets reflect the needs and demands of the people in each Member State. These are more than sufficient reasons to vote against the proposal.

 
  
 		 

  Louis Michel (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) The euro crisis is closely linked to the differences between Member States with regard to their economic and budgetary policies. The establishment of a ‘European Semester’ or ‘economic governance’ was therefore vital. The aim, with this new EU economic and budgetary policy coordination tool, is to check that Member States are applying budgetary discipline and to ensure that the Europe 2020 programme is being implemented properly by granting it adequate financial resources. With the introduction of the European Semester, we are one step closer to European integration. However, we should remember that parliamentary debate on the main economic policy guidelines is the cornerstone of every democratic system. Democratic debate must not be overlooked. I therefore fully support Ms Berès when she calls for complete transparency with regard to the amendments made to the country-specific recommendations following discussions with the Member States.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – The initial goal of the report was to assess the first cycle of the European Semester. With the new developments on economic governance, the scope of the report has been broadened to focus on the way to upgrade the parliamentary dimension of economic governance with two main proposals: reinforce the European Parliament’s role within a codecision process for the European Semester; and reinforce cooperation between the European Parliament and national parliaments. In favour.

 
  
 		 

  Andreas Mölzer (NI), in writing. – (DE) It is a sad fact for the entire global economy that the Eurocrats in Brussels have failed to take any constructive steps in dealing with the financial and economic crisis that has lasted since 2008. What is even worse is the fact that the European leadership continues to close its eyes to any sensible alternative for resolving the problem. Instead, they continue along the wrong path first chosen at the end of the 1990s, when the euro was launched. In their desperation, the Eurocrats can think of no better remedy than to call for even greater centralisation in Brussels. However, instead of shifting more powers to Brussels with the European Semester, what we should be doing is preventing the indebtedness in the first place. In view of the morass that is the debt crisis, the priority should be at all costs to prevent the economically sound members of the euro area from being dragged into the abyss too. Since the European Semester does not offer any rational solutions in this regard, I voted against it.

 
  
 		 

  Claudio Morganti (EFD), in writing. – (IT) I decided to vote against this report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. This is because the entire analysis is based on and geared towards the Europe 2020 strategy, an initiative that is completely failing to bear the expected fruits, perhaps partly as a result of the crisis. However, it is not the first time that these much heralded strategies have turned out to be overwhelming failures, and the crisis cannot be used as an excuse for the expected failure of the Europe 2020 strategy as well. Focusing many of the objectives of economic policy coordination on this strategy looks to me like a move that is risky at best. I must also add that, in various points, it seems to be a case of coordinating the social policies of Member States, rather than their economies. The semester of coordination has only been in place for a few months, but I think that its value and meaning ought to be different from the content of this report.

 
  
 		 

  Franz Obermayr (NI), in writing. – (DE) Instead of finally giving a chance to weaker national economies outside the euro area, Brussels is now placing its hopes in a planned economy. Economic and social policy, in other words, the key competences of a sovereign state, are now subject to the centralist monitoring of the Commission and the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (Ecofin). National reform programmes have to be presented in Brussels so that ‘anomalies can be identified at an early stage’. The recommendations of the Council and the Commission are then to be implemented in the second semester. This system will never work. This is not just my opinion – a study by the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance comes to the same conclusion: it estimates the efficiency of the recommendations in the last semester as non-existent. Why is that? Growth cannot be forced through a centralised planned economy. We need to remedy the mistakes made when the euro area was established and form a hard currency zone. This must be made up of sovereign states with sovereign economic policies. For this reason, I have voted against this report.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this resolution because well learnt lessons from the past can provide a bridge to a successful future. When assessing the experience of the first wave of the crisis, EU institutions and Member States should not just look differently at the future but also examine the current situation differently, but this is often not the case. However, the world has changed significantly in recent years. The directives being adopted are not effective enough to overcome the new challenges arising every day and ever growing old challenges in the economic, financial and social fields. Today, the main issue on the EU agenda is that of the scale of unemployment in Member States. We must implement urgent measures and programmes to ensure that unemployment is reduced by at least a third as quickly as possible. I believe that the Commission should, as soon as possible, envisage and submit specific plans laying down measures which enable progress to be made in implementing the main immediate and short-term objectives in the areas of job creation, innovation, education, energy and social inclusion.

 
  
 		 

  Alfredo Pallone (PPE), in writing. – (IT) We have adopted the ‘six-pack’, and the two new regulations proposed by the Commission last week further emphasise fiscal and budgetary discipline and supervision by the EU institutions. Quite rightly, we need to go back to having rules on budgetary discipline, and procedures must be automatic. However, we cannot forget growth, because if we straightjacket our state budgets through unbending rules, while also requiring rigorous structural reforms, then, at the same time, we have to bring in measures to stimulate growth. Otherwise, in overall terms, Europe or many Member States risk falling into recession. Amidst all this, we cannot forget the relationship with our citizens and that is why, in the report by Ms Berès on the European Semester, we are asking for greater involvement from the national parliaments and from this House. That is because what this crisis has shown, above all in the search for responses, is precisely the lack of unity and political leadership and the democratic deficit with our citizens.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted for this report because I agree with its main thrusts and recommendations. I would like to stress the need for the Commission and the Member States to step up support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which constitute the backbone of the single market economy, in accordance with the findings of the Annual Growth Survey, in particular, by fully implementing the Small Business Act, and by means of a package of measures to eliminate the obstacles faced by SMEs when accessing funding. Such a measure is of extreme importance in the outermost regions.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The aim of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination was to introduce a way of synchronising European and national economic and financial policies. Today, any effort to conceptualise the political world that attempts to explain the current reality will tend to point to a ‘web-like political reality’ or, rather, ‘polyarchical’ power and webs of ‘interconstitutionality’. The purpose of this is to explain how the decisions made by one political player have an impact on all the others.

The real issue is therefore to determine to what extent democratic legitimacy can be brought to bear at a time when traditional decision-making procedures no longer appear to be offering a suitable response. Therefore, while it is no longer possible to preserve the traditional concept of sovereignty, which, in practice, would be profoundly unrealistic, it is still possible to secure the concurrence of powers and to involve the national parliaments and the European Parliament, which are directly legitimised institutions, as fellow players. If not, political power will lose a significant part of its legitimacy, which will jeopardise the basic choices that need to be made. I voted in favour, since I believe the report addresses these issues.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. The outcome of the draft report (see link A7-0384/2011) of the ECON committee is the result of a long process. Nine committees drafted opinions which are well reflected in the final text as the rapporteur decided to vote most of them in a chapter called ‘sectoral contributions to the European Semester’. More than 350 amendments were tabled in ECON. In order to avoid the ‘left-right’ clash of the economic governance package, Ms Berès opted for a smart and inclusive process of negotiation which led to a good outcome. Most key Green amendments (47) survived through the negotiation process, including the following very good elements: - The EP commits to organise a public hearing to hold a dialogue based on the ‘comply or explain’ principle with the Commission and the Council at which the recommendations from the Commission, and the changes introduced by the Council, would be discussed. - The report emphasises that the guidelines for the employment policies of Member States and the broad economic guidelines both form integral parts of the European Semester and are equally important for the achievement of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The report also asks the Council and the Commission to ensure that all policy recommendations are consistent with the integrated guidelines.

 
  
 		 

  Tokia Saïfi (PPE), in writing. – (FR) In May 2010, the Commission proposed the introduction of a semester of stricter budgetary surveillance. This process has been in force since January 2011. The objective of the European Semester is to strengthen coordination between Member States and European institutions while the budget lines for the following year are still at the draft stage. In particular, it is about ensuring that national budgets are fully compatible, firstly, with the stability or convergence programmes presented a few months earlier and, secondly, with the economic guidelines laid down at European level. During those six months (January to July), the budgetary and structural policies of Member States will be reviewed, on the basis of the information they provide, in order to identify any possible inconsistencies or signs of imbalance. I supported this resolution on the first European Semester because it calls for, among other things, increased parliamentary control of euro area governance at national and European level alike. It is only right that the people’s representatives be involved in strengthening the legitimacy of Community action and analysing the measures proposed.

 
  
 		 

  Nikolaos Salavrakos (EFD), in writing. – (EL) I voted in favour of the report by Ms Berès because I consider that she has presented a very good text which strikes a balance between the social and economic dimensions of economic governance measures. The emphasis needs to be on growth and the competitiveness of the EU. This being so, it is a good idea to harmonise the national economic policies of the Member States of the EU in order to meet EU 2020 strategy targets.

 
  
 		 

  Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE), in writing. – (PL) What is known as the European Semester, or, in other words, procedures for coordinating the economic policy of the EU Member States, has now been in force for a year. This procedure was introduced in the wake of the economic crisis that emerged largely as a result of excessive debt.

Today, we are at the epicentre of the biggest economic crisis in the history of the EU, and we can be quite sure that the European Semester is not enough to restore the confidence of financial markets or to restore growth. It is obvious that it must be followed up with more measures, which we eagerly await. At the moment, in the first year of the European Semester, it is difficult to predict whether this instrument will perform its function. Although more and more Member States are implementing the Commission’s recommendations, such as raising the pension age, facilitating access to capital and using public procurement to stimulate the economy, we still lack determination and coordination at European level. We must hope that, along with a streamlined European Semester, future solutions for the coordination of EU economic policy, which we expect soon following the December summit, will deliver the expected results and contribute to Europe’s rapid recovery from the debt crisis.

 
  
 		 

  József Szájer (PPE), in writing. – (HU) During the crisis, it has become clear to all of us that the EU must engage in stricter budgetary control. Accordingly, under the European Semester, our principal aim is to coordinate Member State budgetary and economic policies in line with the Stability and Growth Pact and the Europe 2020 economic strategy.

The most important task ahead of us now is to create an instrument for the prevention of future public debt crises which is effective at Community level.
