However, a vital prerequisite of this is the introduction of stricter sanctions. The greatest merit of the legislative ‘six-pack’ drafted during the Hungarian Presidency is that it gave priority to keeping state expenditures in check, and to the importance of the debt criterion.

Increased coordination of Member State economic policies is a necessary but insufficient condition of recovery from the crisis. In order for us to be able to manage the consequences of the recession and establish a sustainable economic policy, we must, in any event, pursue stricter budgetary control. Hungary has already embarked on this path. Unfortunately, my country is among the most indebted in Europe. The extreme amount of state debt we currently have is a result of irresponsible management by previous socialist governments.

In order to put an end to the indebtedness of the country once and for all, Hungary has adopted provisions at constitutional level on responsible budgetary management and a state debt limit this year.

I recommend that European Union Member States follow the example of the Hungarian Basic Law. They should put a constitutional stop to indebtedness so as to prevent another Greek, Irish or Portuguese crisis.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The European Semester is a process for coordinating Member States’ economic policies, and is implemented by the European Union to enforce budgetary discipline as well as to ensure compliance with the Europe 2020 strategy. I agree with this report because the European institutions have adopted new measures aimed at helping Member States to correct excessive deficits and to establish greater coordination of their economic and budgetary policies.

However, I should like to point out that the European Semester cannot, and should not, replace the democratic legitimacy of the European Parliament and national parliaments; the situation should always be monitored by the respective parliamentary committee. As a member of the Committee on Regional Development, I should like to stress that a strong and properly financed cohesion policy is the only effective and efficient instrument for implementing the Europe 2020 strategy. It is therefore important to highlight its long-term development programmes, budgetary dimension and decentralised management system.

 
  
 		 

  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. The economic and financial crisis has made some Member States cut public expenditure and investment in areas which are essential to Europe’s citizens, such as health and education. I regard it as important that both the Commission and the Council ensure that sustainable, inclusive growth is at the heart of all the policy proposals made as part of the European Semester, along with employment and job creation. The measures adopted as part of the national reform plans, aimed at implementing economic governance and the European Semester, must not exacerbate the social crisis. I advocate that the recommendations from the Commission and Council must be mainly focused on a social policy conducive to education and vocational training, access to employment, the reintegration of the unemployed into the labour market and better coordination of Member States’ social welfare systems. Furthermore, the EU must consolidate the internal market and remove the barriers preventing workers’ mobility within the EU. I call for the Commission’s recommendations, specific to each country, to be accompanied by assessments of the social impact, taking into account the promotion of employment and the guarantee of access to education and ongoing training programmes.

 
  
 		 

  Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (FR) I voted against the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination because, although it adopts a relatively critical tone, it is still in keeping with the Europe 2020 strategy, with the efforts to strengthen the single market and the ‘six-pack’, and, in particular, with the Wortmann-Kool report. This just goes to show that some MEPs are talking out of both sides of their mouths. There is no point in saying here that parliamentary approval of public budgets is one of the foundations of democracy when the legislative texts say otherwise. Yet again, economic policies are being prioritised over social issues. This report will have no effect on current European policies. I therefore have no reason to change my vote against the ‘six-pack’.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) The European Semester mechanism ensures the coordination of the necessary budgetary policy and fiscal policy between the Member States, giving them enough room for effective budgetary, economic and social measures. The much-vaunted synergy effects can only be optimised through this coordination. In essence, the European Parliament requires that sufficient resources should be set aside at an early stage, so that the objectives of the 2020 strategy can be implemented. I voted in favour.

 
  
  

Motion for a resolution: B7-0576/2011

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for this report and will highlight some of the most relevant points for strengthening our internal market: the possibility of using a European professional card; an effective conflict resolution system; a single point of contact; the review of public procurement legislation and the commitment of the Heads of State or Government to comply with the Single Market Act.

 
  
 		 

  Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D), in writing. – (LT) The proper and smooth functioning of the single market is an essential condition for the free movement of people, goods, services and capital within the EU and for ensuring its economic development. We will mark an important event in 2012 – the twentieth anniversary of the creation of the single market, and it is therefore important to know and understand how the single market will develop in the future and what the concerns and expectations of participants in the single market are. In October this year, the Single Market Forum, organised at the initiative of the Commission and the Polish Presidency, showed that there are still many legal and administrative obstacles to the smooth functioning of the single market. I believe that implementation of the Single Market Act should be monitored at the highest political level, and that the Commission should regularly review its implementation and the transposition of the relevant legislation into Member States’ national law and issue reports. I welcome the fact that the resolution calls for the completion of the digital single market and for remaining technical barriers to cross-border trade and service provision to be overcome, in particular, by improving the mutual recognition of electronic IDs, electronic signatures and electronic documents. I wish to stress the importance of establishing common principles of public procurement at EU level since this would enable a number of remaining administrative and bureaucratic obstacles to be eliminated and would provide more opportunities, in particular for SMEs, to develop cross-border activities.

 
  
 		 

  Regina Bastos (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The single market has brought about enormous benefits for the 500 million European citizens and has given European businesses new opportunities to expand. This resolution suggests that the points of single contact be developed into fully-fledged e-Government centres allowing entrepreneurs to submit and manage administrative formalities online.

The Digital Single Market will only be complete once technical setbacks to cross-border trade and to the provision of cross-border services have been overcome. The public procurement sector needs to be professionalised, and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) need to step up their involvement in the award of public contracts. This resolution also suggests the use of an effective, accessible and straightforward alternative dispute-resolution system. It is clear that the Digital Single Market promotes innovation, which, with the support of the Commission’s coordinated initiatives and the commitment of the Member States, will create new opportunities for businesses, particularly SMEs. This will encourage job creation and social cohesion and will lead to sustainable economic growth; it will also meet the social needs of European consumers and citizens. I voted for this resolution for these reasons.

 
  
 		 

  Alain Cadec (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of the resolution on the Single Market Forum. The creation of this forum is part of the Single Market Act, which is a strategic document for planning legislative and non-legislative initiatives aimed at relaunching the single market in 2012. The resolution sets out proposals for ensuring that the forum is used as an opportunity to relaunch the single market, which makes a significant contribution to Europe’s competitiveness, effectively.

 
  
 		 

  Edite Estrela (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I have voted in favour of this resolution as I support the conversion of the Single Market Forum into a regular event, with the purpose of enabling businesses and citizens, as well as local and regional authorities, to participate directly in and influence the further development of the Single Market.

 
  
 		 

  Diogo Feio (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The single market and the policies related to it have brought benefits to 500 million European consumers and 21 million European businesses and have become the engine for economic growth. At this moment, when everything is taking place at a European level, I must underline the importance of the single market for European integration itself, greater social cohesion, sustainable development, economic competitiveness and growth, which enable us to face up to present constraints and future developments and to compete in a globalised world. In this regard, I welcome the idea of establishing a forum which meets regularly to consider the future and the development of the single market.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The present motion for a resolution, tabled in response to a statement by the Commission pursuant to Rule 110(2) of the Rules of Procedure, concerns the first Single Market Forum, held in the Polish city of Kraków on 3-4 October 2011. The economic crisis cannot make us oblivious to the human aspects of the reforms, such as the wellbeing of citizens, consumers, workers and savers. The purpose of this forum, which involved more than 1 300 participants (businesses, social partners, NGOs, European institutions, public authorities, etc.), was to discuss strategies for improving the functioning of the single market, such as promoting freedom of movement among European citizens through the automatic recognition of professional qualifications, speeding up the online Alternative Dispute Resolution system, transforming Points of Single Contact, protecting the interests of online purchasers, creating the European patent, etc. I am voting in favour of this resolution and welcome the attention it gives to small and medium-sized enterprises, the real engines of the European economy, which have the power to bring about recovery from the current economic and financial crisis by means of sustainable economic growth, thus making the single market economy increasingly dynamic and competitive.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) We have here an initiative and a resolution that are highly significant for the majority in this Parliament. The first recital in the resolution is, in fact, very revealing when it declares that ‘the European Single Market has brought tremendous benefits to 500 million Europeans, whilst opening up new opportunities for expansion for more than 21 million European businesses, and has become the real engine for growth within the European economy’. This ignores a basic fact: in the actual conditions under which this process of integration is taking place, the opportunities referred to really have arisen for some people, while, for others, they have remained mere promises, endlessly postponed, and have turned into nightmares.

Some have experienced real expansion, others only a long-drawn-out death and disappearance. Free-market competition has made life easy for the sections of society that wield economic and financial power, but has aggravated unemployment, increased the rate of bankruptcy among countless small and medium-sized enterprises, and done nothing to improve the day-to-day lives of the general population, as the present crisis is making plain. It is for these reasons that, on being presented with such a picture as this resolution puts before us, our only response can be to protest against the pressure being exerted here to entrench the single market yet further, which the rhetoric of ‘consultation’ and ‘participation’ essentially does nothing to change.

 
  
 		 

  Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) We have voted against this resolution, which declares as its very first point: ‘whereas the European Single Market has brought tremendous benefits to 500 million Europeans, whilst opening up new opportunities for expansion for more than 21 million European businesses, and has become the real engine for growth within the European economy’. Really, such a declaration cannot be allowed to pass when we bear in mind that free-market competition has made life easy for the sections of society that wield economic and financial power, but has aggravated unemployment, increased the rate of bankruptcy among micro-enterprises and SMEs and done nothing to improve the day-to-day lives of the general population, as the present crisis is making plain.

Thus, even though the Single Market Forum may be converted into a regular event to enable businesses and citizens, as well as local and regional authorities, to participate directly in and influence the further development of the single market, the truth remains that the current state of affairs is quite different from that proclaimed in this report. Similarly, we disagree with the pressure being exerted here to further entrench the single market.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Benová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) The European Single Market has brought tremendous benefits to 500 million Europeans, whilst opening up new opportunities for expansion for more than 21 million European businesses, and has become the real engine for growth within the European economy. In a large number of areas, there is still a gap between what people expect from the single market and what they experience in practice. The first Single Market Forum brought together European businesses, social partners, non-governmental organisations, think-tanks, journalists, national Parliaments, European institutions, public authorities at various levels of government and European citizens. It is important that this forum becomes a regular event, to enable businesses and citizens as well as local and regional authorities to directly participate in, and thereby collectively influence, the further development of the single market. I believe that it would be appropriate to create a Single Market Forum on-line, as a platform open to the general public, enabling them to keep abreast of single market developments and share experiences and current single market concerns. It is necessary for governments, regional and local entities, businesses, trade unions and non-governmental organisations to cooperate to ensure that single market rules work effectively on the ground for citizens and businesses.

 
  
 		 

  Philippe Juvin (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I supported this resolution, as it sets out the main lessons learnt from the first Single Market Forum, held in Kraków last October. In my opinion, this initiative is very important when it comes to analysing and debating the shortcomings of the internal market and to finding solutions to strengthen it. The large number of stakeholders present illustrates the need to establish a proper dialogue with all those involved.

 
  
 		 

  Juozas Imbrasas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I welcomed this resolution because the Single Market Forum would be converted into a regular event to enable businesses and citizens, as well as local and regional authorities, to directly participate in and influence the further development of the single market. The European single market contributes positively to innovation and, underpinned by coordinated Commission initiatives and a strong commitment from the Member States, will generate new opportunities for businesses – particularly innovative SMEs – and will strongly support job creation and social cohesion and bring about sustainable economic growth, as well as meet the needs of EU citizens and consumers. National governments, regional and local institutions, businesses, trade unions and non-governmental organisations must cooperate to ensure that single market rules work effectively on the ground for citizens and businesses.

 
  
 		 

  Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE), in writing. – (LV) Given that the European Union’s single market is important for Latvia, its businesses and development, and for increasing its standard of living, and given that there are many obstacles to the functioning of this market, I voted for the resolution on the Outcome of the Single Market Forum. This resolution provides for converting the Single Market Forum into a regular event, calls on Member States to ensure the correct application of internal market legislation, and highlights the increasing significance of the digital market. I consider that representatives from Latvia, too, should join this forum, as its importance may increase.

 
  
 		 

  George Lyon (ALDE), in writing. – I welcome the work done by the Single Market Forum in an effort to join forces to relaunch the single market in this difficult context of economic crisis. I would like to use this opportunity to insist on two points: 1 - The need to make the single market a reality for all European citizens and businesses so as to make it the real engine for growth in the European Union. The priority measures that the Commission will come up with in the coming months in the Single Market Act should focus on the need to drive sustainable and innovative economic growth, hand in hand with initiatives taken by Member States and the business community to boost growth in the EU at a time of economic recession. 2 - The single market must, as a matter of priority, generate new opportunities for businesses in Europe, starting with innovative SMEs. The Small Business Act principle must underpin all initiatives taken in the framework of the single market, to create a small business-friendly environment for our enterprises to thrive on the markets, accompanied by sound and fair regulation which does not create additional unnecessary burdens on SMEs which are the core of our potential for growth in Europe.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I voted for this resolution which ‘Recalls the importance of simplification and proper implementation of public procurement rules and therefore calls on the Commission and the Member States to ensure it in the existing and upcoming legal framework; notes the need to professionalise the public procurement sector through improved training, to confirm procurement objectives and to explore possible ways of achieving other policy objectives; considers that the participation of SMEs in public procurement tenders needs to be improved and that procurement procedures need to be less cumbersome, cheaper and more open to SMEs, and underlines the need for an extended use of the ‘most economically advantageous tender’ principle instead of the ‘cheapest price’ principle’.

 
  
 		 

  Mario Mauro (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The single market is now one of the most important assurances that we have for reviving the European economy, but is also the starting point for the complete fulfilment of the European project. I voted in favour of this resolution since I have no doubt that there should be an ever-increasing number of events designed to involve citizens in the European project. The Single Market Forum has been a success for this very reason.

 
  
 		 

  Mairead McGuinness (PPE), in writing. – The Single Market Forum provides an opportunity for businesses and citizens and local and regional authorities to directly participate in, and influence further, the development of the Single Market which has, thus far, benefited up to 200 million Europeans and opened up new opportunities for expansion for more than 21 million European businesses. I voted in favour of this resolution.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This Single Market Forum, held in Kraków on 3-4 October 2011, brought together European businesses, social partners, non-governmental organisations, think-tanks, journalists, national Parliaments, European institutions, public authorities at various levels of government and European citizens. In my opinion, it should become a regular event, so enabling everyone to exert a greater influence on the further development of the single market. The present motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to put forward all 12 priorities in the Single Market Act by the end of 2011 so as to enable the Council and the European Parliament to adopt a first set of priority measures by the end of 2012 and to impart new impetus to the single market, since this is crucial to European economic growth.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – As a follow-up of the Single Market Act, Parliament organised jointly with the Commission and the Polish Presidency the ‘Single Market Forum’ in Kraków this October. The event brought together politicians, stakeholders (trade unions, businesses, NGOs, etc.) and citizens to discuss the functioning, problems and future of the single market. As requested in the Single Market Act Report of the Parliament, the Single Market Forum is foreseen to be an annual or biannual event, in order to evaluate and discuss the further development of the single market. I voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I welcome this resolution. Above all, I believe that the Single Market Forum should be organised regularly. Only in this way will businesses, citizens and local and regional authorities be able to directly participate in the further activities of the single market and be active participants in its development. It should be borne in mind that the single market has brought huge benefits to Europeans. It has created prosperity and jobs. However, many citizens, consumers and SMEs still do not have enough information and knowledge concerning their rights and opportunities in the single market. Consequently, I believe that the Commission must draw up and adopt a charter of citizens’ rights setting out citizens’ rights and obligations in the single market. This charter would be addressed to all citizens moving, working, buying and selling at cross-border level. Only once these measures have been implemented will we achieve better two-way communication and create effective means of making use of our rights.

 
  
 		 

  Alfredo Pallone (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Single Market Forum, which was held on 3-4 October in Kraków. Over the 20 years between borders being opened and today, the single market has given truly significant impetus to the European economy, changing citizens’ lives for the better. Today, we remain confident in the growth potential of the European single market for addressing the financial crisis. That is why, moreover, I hope that the Single Market Forum will be held regularly so as to allow businesses, citizens and local and regional administrations to take part in it directly and influence the future evolution of the European market.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I have voted in favour of the present resolution since I agree with the appeal by the European Parliament to the Commission and the Member States to involve citizens and other stakeholders more closely in the development of the single market, in particular, by organising timely public consultations on new legislation in a more proactive way, in partnership with national and local stakeholders and social partners, as well as with NGOs and the media.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) According to the list presented by the rapporteur, the recent Single Market Forum brought together European businesses, social partners, non-governmental organisations, think-tanks, journalists, national parliaments, European institutions, public authorities at various levels of government and European citizens. It was therefore an occasion to think about the European system of free movement of persons, goods, services and capital, which currently allows the free movement of 500 million people. This has been the basis for the communitarian project, strengthening trading relations between the countries involved, hence their interdependence, and so making Europe an area of peace and harmony.

The single market, or its potential, thus deserves the consideration of European analysts, as well as commitment on the part of the Union’s institutions to constantly strengthen the mechanisms of economic integration, without losing sight of the reason why they were established. These are principles with which I myself identify and which have therefore gained my support.

 
  
 		 

  Robert Rochefort (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of the resolution on the Single Market Forum. The first forum, which was held in October, enabled businesses, citizens, social partners, NGOs and public authorities at various levels to share their specific experiences and proposals regarding the current functioning of the single market. This exercise, which has the advantage of tapping various decentralised sources and of developing on the basis of the problems encountered on the ground, will most certainly be repeated. In 2012, we are even going to organise a ‘Single Market Week’ across all countries in the Union. In these times of economic crisis and uncertainty, it is more necessary than ever to give fresh impetus to the single market. To achieve this, the gap between what Europeans expect of the single market and what they actually get out of it will need to be bridged (let us remember, in this context, citizens’, consumers’ and SMEs’ lack of knowledge regarding their rights, obligations and opportunities in the single market). Its success will also need to be proven, through a demonstration of the prosperity it can bring to all Europeans, wherever they may be in the Union and whatever their nationality.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. The EP: 1. Stresses the importance of converting the Single Market Forum into a regular event, to enable businesses and citizens, as well as local and regional authorities, to directly participate in and influence the further development of the single market; 2. Calls on the Commission to work with Member States, applicant countries and EEA partners to hold and promote major public events in 2012 in order to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the single market; considers that the objective should be at least one event in all participating countries, with regional activities as appropriate, linked to a central, main EU event, possibly organised with the EU Presidency; 3. Calls on the Commission to put forward all 12 priorities in the Single Market Act by the end of 2011 to enable the Council and the European Parliament, in close cooperation with the Commission, to adopt a first set of priority measures by the end of 2012 to impart new impetus to the single market.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The Single Market Forum, held in Kraków (Poland) on 3-4 October 2011, brought together European businesses, social partners, non-governmental organisations, think-tanks, journalists, national parliaments, European institutions, public authorities at various levels of government and European citizens, and must be converted into a regular event to enable businesses and citizens, as well as local and regional authorities, to participate directly in and influence the further development of the single market.

In the motion for a resolution, which has received my support, the Commission is called on to put forward all 12 priorities in the Single Market Act by the end of 2011 so as to enable the Council and the European Parliament, in close cooperation with the Commission, to adopt a first set of priority measures by the end of 2012 and to impart new impetus to the single market, which is the real engine of European economic growth. The European Parliament also invited the Commission to work with Member States, applicant countries and EEA partners to hold and promote major public events in 2012 to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the single market.

 
  
 		 

  Tokia Saïfi (PPE), in writing. – (FR) It was the Single Market Act, adopted in early 2011, that led to the decision to set up this forum, the first of which was held last October. It was attended by over 1 000 participants from different sectors of society (businesses, social partners, NGOs, think-tanks, members of the national parliaments, members of the European institutions and representatives of national public authorities) and laid the groundwork for a number of actions to be undertaken ahead of the 20th anniversary of the single market, in 2012. In my opinion, one of these actions is of the utmost importance: modernising the rules on public procurement. We need to rethink our tender rules quickly in order to cope with competition from third countries and to ensure that European companies are on a level playing field where procurement outside the European Union is concerned. The European Commission promised us a specific instrument by the end of 2011, yet it has already been severely delayed, putting our companies into difficulty. Our companies are competitive, but they are being held back by outdated legislation. This situation cannot continue.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) The European internal market offers enormous advantages to around 500 million people, including in terms of tendering and price benefits, providing over 21 million European businesses with new opportunities for expansion. The Commission is to table specific proposals for the 12 priorities of the Single Market Act by the end of 2011, so that the Council and Parliament will be able to agree a first package of measures by the end of 2012. I voted in favour.

 
  
  

Motion for a resolution: B7-0615/2011

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for this report, and would stress that the Commission and Member States should provide adequate financing and investment to carry out the research needed to effectively implement HIV programmes that promote equal and timely access for all to HIV tests, treatment and therapy. I also call on all the Member States to gear their policies towards putting an end to the discrimination and social exclusion usually associated with people living with HIV/AIDS, so as to protect their fundamental rights.

 
  
 		 

  Roberta Angelilli (PPE), in writing. – (IT) A general EU response to HIV/AIDS is needed since this virus and illness affects 2.2 million people in the EU and neighbouring countries. According to the latest available data, around 26 000 people are infected each year in Europe and adjacent countries, and it is estimated that more than 30% of those infected are not aware of it. The Union must provide an effective and tailor-made response to the evolution and spread of this virus in order to fight it and help those already infected. It is a good thing that the Commission and the Council are acting swiftly to apply the communication entitled ‘Combating HIV/AIDS in the EU and neighbouring countries 2009-2013’. Positive, too, is the implementation of a specific action plan to fight against further infections, which is primarily made up of numerous information and awareness campaigns that will make everyone understand the severity of this phenomenon.

 
  
 		 

  Sophie Auconie (PPE), in writing. – (FR) On this day, 1 December, World AIDS Day, I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the European Commission and the Member States to do everything they can to improve AIDS prevention and to further combat discrimination against HIV-positive people. Given that almost 26 000 new cases of AIDS were reported in Europe in 2009, the AIDS campaign must not be undermined in any way.

 
  
 		 

  Regina Bastos (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The HIV/AIDS epidemic has been a priority issue for the European Union. The EU is committed, above all, to promoting preventive measures and public awareness, improving monitoring facilities, forming networks among important participants in the fight against HIV/AIDS and encouraging the spread of good practice

Unfortunately, the number of HIV infections is rising at an alarming rate, particularly in Eastern Europe, and is accompanied by a great number of cases of infected sufferers who have not yet been diagnosed. In response to this, the present motion for a resolution makes an urgent call for cooperation across borders and disciplines to combat the epidemic. Special attention must still be paid to the problems faced by the countries neighbouring the EU, bearing in mind that HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases know no frontiers.

I am sorry that the present resolution includes a reference to abortion and emergency contraception. As I understand it, these matters fall outside the purport of the present resolution and raise extremely delicate moral questions. I therefore voted against that paragraph and consequently abstained from the final vote on the resolution.

 
  
 		 

  Maria Da Graça Carvalho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted for this motion for a resolution because I believe HIV/AIDS is a preventable disease and that primary prevention interventions, such as providing information, new skills, better services, products needed to protect people from the virus and promote safer forms of behaviour, are central to the efforts to prevent the spread of HIV. Given that there is an urgent need to step up the development and implementation of comprehensive prevention approaches, along with continued investment in research into and development of new prevention technologies, I hereby express my support for this report.

 
  
 		 

  Carlos Coelho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The rate at which the number of HIV infections is rising in Europe, particularly Eastern Europe, is quite alarming. In 2009, more than 25 000 new cases of HIV infection were diagnosed in the EU. Cross-border and cross-disciplinary cooperation is therefore essential to help address the epidemic, and it is unacceptable that there is still such a marked difference between Member States in access to HIV prevention, treatment and support services. I therefore agree there is an urgent need for more equitable access to HIV prevention in the EU, as well as to the relevant testing and treatment, while, at the same time, the necessary resources must be guaranteed. I believe the text of the resolution is well balanced overall and correctly brings across the principle that ‘the enemy is HIV, rather than HIV carriers’. Unfortunately, partisan pressure from some Members has led to the inclusion of a reference to abortion, which is unrelated. I will not be able to vote in favour because of that, and I would stress the contradiction between safeguarding life and health and attempting to justify abortion.

 
  
 		 

  Christine De Veyrac (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of this resolution. It calls on the European Union to develop, as quickly as possible, measures to combat this scourge, which affects every single one of our populations.

 
  
 		 

  Ioan Enciu (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for this resolution because AIDS is a fully preventable disease, and primary prevention interventions, especially through providing information, skills and the necessary services and products, are key to preventing the spread of HIV. We see at the moment an alarming rise in the number of people infected with HIV. This is a particularly significant problem, especially in Eastern Europe. I support the call made to the Commission and Council for the necessary resources to be invested to guarantee fair access to HIV prevention measures, and I think that the social stigma issue needs to be dealt with comprehensively. At the same time, I believe that the Commission should develop joint EU actions and approaches to promoting full respect for human rights, as well as information campaigns to combat the stigmatisation of and the discrimination suffered by people living with HIV/AIDS. Last but not least, Member States have a duty to take all necessary action to end the discrimination suffered by people living with this virus, especially regarding access to, and the terms and cost of, insurance services.

 
  
 		 

  Edite Estrela (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I voted for this resolution because I believe access to HIV/AIDS prevention and the relevant tests and treatment should be more equitable in the EU. The EU needs to be equipped with the necessary resources to fight this scourge. The economic and financial crisis cannot be allowed to have a negative impact on investment in areas essential to combating this disease.

 
  
 		 

  Diogo Feio (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Today, on World AIDS Day, I reaffirm my absolute commitment to ensuring a global, humane and effective response in the fight against HIV/AIDS, and my conviction that the way forward is to improve access to prevention and to the treatments available, as the text of this resolution advocates. However, I was unable to vote for the resolution because of the adoption of a paragraph of the text that advocates, and I quote, ‘access to … safe and legal abortion’. Since I believe this is a subject that comes under the competence of the Member States and not the European Union and, furthermore, since I do not view an important resolution on the EU’s global response to the scourge of HIV/AIDS as an appropriate place to advocate ‘access to … safe and legal abortion’, I abstained in the final vote on the motion. Today, however, I must appeal to all the Member States to continue investing in equitable access to HIV/AIDS prevention, diagnosis and treatment, so that the severe economic crisis we are experiencing does not become a terrible opportunity for a rise in the number of new infections and of undiagnosed and untreated cases.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This motion for a resolution, further to an oral question pursuant to Rule 115(5) of the Rules of Procedure, in the form of a mid-term review of the Commission communication to the Council and the European Parliament on ‘Combating HIV/AIDS in the EU and neighbouring countries 2009-2013’, concerns the EU response to HIV/AIDS, not only within the EU, but also in neighbouring countries. Despite the progress made in fighting this scourge, we cannot lower our guard, because 161 000 new cases appeared in the EU and neighbouring countries in 2009, out of a total of more than 2.2 million, 45% of them women under the age of 20. It is crucial to devote efforts to informing people and avoiding social exclusion. I offer my solidarity to the victims and my support to those who are working to wipe this scourge from the face of the planet. I call on all the Member States and all the EU institutions to make the greatest possible commitment to eradicating this disease and fighting the social exclusion of victims.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) HIV infections are increasing at an alarming rate in Europe. In 2009, nearly 26 000 new cases were diagnosed and reported by the countries of the European Union and European Economic Area, whereas more than 160 000 people were infected in neighbouring countries. These figures show that no slackening in the efforts to combat HIV can be tolerated. It is a pity that the same majority that solemnly acknowledges it, when it is a matter of marking World AIDS Day, turns a blind eye to the investment cuts being made in both preventing and fighting the disease. These investment cuts are due to the overall cuts being made under so-called austerity measures, which the majority here endorses.

This is clearly illustrated in Portugal by the decision that has just been announced to close the telephone helpline (Linha SIDA or ‘AIDS Line’), together with a series of other measures threatening the vital efforts being made in the fields of both prevention and treatment. It is important to bear in mind that access to prevention, treatment and support services is very unequal in the various Member States, and therefore it is essential to work towards mitigating such differences by investing the resources needed to ensure equitable access to these services in every country.

 
  
 		 

  Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) As we know, HIV infections are increasing at an alarming rate in Europe. In 2009, nearly 26 000 new cases were diagnosed and reported by the countries of the European Union and European Economic Area. In the EU’s neighbours, however, more than 160 000 people were infected. These figures show that no slackening in the efforts to combat HIV can be tolerated. It is a pity that the same majority that solemnly acknowledges it, when it is a matter of marking World AIDS Day, turns a blind eye to the investment cuts being made both in prevention and in fighting the disease because of budget cuts.

This is clearly illustrated in Portugal by the decision that has just been announced to close the telephone helpline (Linha SIDA or ‘AIDS Line’), together with a series of other measures threatening the vital efforts being made in the fields of both prevention and treatment. It is important to bear in mind that access to prevention, treatment and support services is very unequal in the various Member States, and therefore it is essential to work towards mitigating such differences by investing the resources needed to ensure equitable access to these services in every country.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Benová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) According to the 2010 Report on HIV Surveillance by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDPC), 25 917 newly diagnosed cases of HIV infection were reported in 2009 by the countries of the European Union and European Economic Area and the number of HIV infections is rising at an alarming rate, particularly in Eastern Europe. A large proportion of HIV infections remain undiagnosed; many people do not know their serostatus and there is a relatively high likelihood that they will discover it only once they are affected by HIV/AIDS-related illnesses. Recent trials have shown the efficacy of early access to treatment in reducing both the infectiousness of patients and the HIV transmission rate. Levels of access to HIV prevention, treatment, care and support services differ significantly between Member States. Social exclusion and discrimination resulting from HIV status, as well as the silence and denial surrounding the infection and the failure to respect the basic human rights of people living with HIV and those belonging to vulnerable groups, persist and continue to undermine HIV prevention, care and treatment, and increase the impact of the epidemic on individuals, families, communities and countries. I firmly believe that we must not allow the economic and financial crisis to have a negative impact on the health sector, or to lead to reduced investments in areas essential to combating HIV/AIDS.

 
  
 		 

  Pat the Cope Gallagher (ALDE), in writing. – The motion for a resolution on the EU response to HIV/AIDS in the EU and neighbouring countries, mid-term review of Commission communication COM(2009)569, contains many positive recommendations. However, we decided to vote against the motion due to an explicit reference to abortion contained in paragraph 22.

 
  
 		 

  Elisabetta Gardini (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Today, we celebrate World AIDS Day. This is a highly significant event that helps maintain a high level of awareness of this complex illness and the worrying rise in the number of people infected. Since 1981, AIDS has killed more than 25 million people, making it one of the most damaging epidemics ever recorded. It is therefore essential for Europe to adopt a common strategy on fighting AIDS/HIV, which must be focused, above all, on prevention and providing detailed and effective information. I think, however, that the approach taken in Parliament’s resolution is not exhaustive and it does not give the right level of attention to the vulnerability of women to this illness. The number of women with HIV in Europe is constantly increasing: women account for some 35% of new diagnoses, in fact. Various studies have also shown that women are doubly at risk of infection through unprotected relations compared with men, which is due in equal measure to cultural restrictions and to women’s greater biological vulnerability. I think, therefore, that the resolution ought to have emphasised the initiatives that could be brought in to improve this situation.

 
  
 		 

  Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) On this day, 1 December, World AIDS Day, I welcome the adoption by Parliament of a resolution reaffirming the European Union’s commitment to combating AIDS alongside those suffering from the disease. Given that over 25 000 new cases of HIV were diagnosed in the European Union in 2010 – up 4% on 2009 – the EU urgently needs to take strong action in this area. Although research has come very far over the last 20 years, it has not succeeded in stopping the spread of the epidemic. Furthermore, an estimated 30% of people living with HIV are unaware that they are carriers. The European Parliament has therefore called for strong measures to support research in this field. What is more, it is prevention and effective screening that we need. Research, prevention and widespread screening: these are the three pillars on which we must focus in the fight against AIDS, so that it quickly becomes a thing of the past.

 
  
 		 

  Sylvie Guillaume (S&D), in writing. – (FR) The number of cases of HIV infection has continued to increase alarmingly in Europe, due in part to advances in combination therapy making the idea of contamination less frightening. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this resolution in order to promote access to comprehensive information on contraception, which is specifically discussed in three paragraphs calling, firstly, for HIV/AIDS prevention programmes to be integrated into sexual and reproductive health and rights programmes; secondly, for Member States to ensure that all national AIDS programmes develop strong linkages between sexual and reproductive health and HIV services; and lastly, for the Commission and Council to ensure access to high-quality, comprehensive sexual and reproductive health services, information and supplies, in particular, confidential and voluntary counselling, testing and treatment; prevention of unintended pregnancies; equitable and affordable access to contraceptives; safe and legal abortion; and care and treatment to prevent vertical transmission of HIV, in particular to children.

 
  
 		 

  Brice Hortefeux (PPE), in writing. – (FR) Today, 1 December, World AIDS Day, the European Parliament has adopted a resolution to step up efforts to combat HIV/AIDS. This resolution comes at a time when the European Commission is about to launch the mid-term review of the action plan in response to HIV/AIDS for the period 2009-2013. Every year, 50 000 new cases are diagnosed in the European Union and neighbouring countries. Within the Union, over 30% of HIV-positive people do not know that they are carriers, and the figure is as high as 70% in neighbouring countries. These figures are cause for alarm and make us realise the urgency of an appropriate response at European and international levels. The fight against HIV/AIDS must remain firmly at the top of the European health care agenda. The EU and its Member States must step up their prevention, testing and awareness campaigns in order to halt this scourge. The sooner an infected person receives a diagnosis, the greater his or her chances of stopping the spread of the virus and the more the risks of transmitting the virus to his or her partners fall.

 
  
 		 

  Salvatore Iacolino (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour because I consider a complete and early diagnosis of the HIV virus to be of fundamental importance in fighting its spread. Indeed, prompt treatment can reduce the patient’s infectivity and cut the rate of HIV transmission up to 96%. Prevention and information are still the cornerstones of suitable and effective health care to protect patients. I also see this resolution in light of the specific context of defending the right to health of the immigrant population, whom must be guaranteed the best possible level of assistance and treatment. We must remember that the UNAIDS 2011 Report claims that 68% of the global population affected by HIV live in sub-Saharan Africa, the starting point for substantial flows of immigrants heading towards Europe. Furthermore, migration often means that migrants become marginalised and exposed to a higher risk of contracting infectious diseases such as HIV/AIDS. Hence, it is important to ensure universal and equal access to prevention, detection tests, treatment and support for people affected by HIV, as well as treatment for co-infections including tuberculosis and hepatitis B and C.

 
  
 		 

  Lívia Járóka (PPE), in writing. – Although there is a slight decrease of new HIV infections on a global scale, the numbers in the EU and neighbouring countries are still rising. According to estimates, almost 30% of European HIV-positive people are totally unaware of their status, resulting in their 3.5 times higher probability of transmitting the virus. Additionally, half of the infected prove to be late for care and progress to late stages of the infection before even being diagnosed. Women and girls are disproportionately affected by HIV and AIDS and current prevention options – such as condoms and abstinence – have proven inadequate in handling the risks that those women face, who are married, want children or are exposed to sexual violence. The four-year action plan of the Commission to reduce new HIV infection throughout Europe must be fully implemented, with special regard to improving access to prevention, treatment and care as well as improving the life conditions of those already infected by HIV. In a broader perspective, universal access to health care, as well as to STD and HIV/AIDS-related prevention, care and support must be facilitated and key populations must be involved in the design, implementation and monitoring.

 
  
 		 

  Philippe Juvin (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I welcome the fact that the resolution on the EU response to HIV/AIDS in the EU and neighbouring countries has been adopted by an overwhelming majority today, World AIDS Day. HIV/AIDS is a serious public health issue: over 50 000 new cases of HIV are diagnosed every year in the European Union and neighbouring countries. The Union must be firm in upholding the commitments it made when it adopted its action plan for the period 2009-2013.

 
  
 		 

  Petru Constantin Luhan (PPE), in writing. – (RO) During the last decade, the number of people infected by HIV has dropped by almost 20% and, for the first time in 2009, more than 50% of HIV-positive women gave birth to uninfected children, thanks to the provision of access to treatment. The progress made is attributable, in particular, to the wider-scale use of antiretroviral drugs. This is precisely why the Commission must continue to use every opportunity available as part of the research and development framework programme to identify funding for promising projects promoting HIV/AIDS research and the development of new antiretroviral drugs, vaccines and innovative microbicides. These encouraging statistics also prove that the Commission and Member States must continue in the future as well to promote information campaigns for providing the general public with clear information about the HIV infection, prevention methods and risky types of behaviour.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I voted for this resolution which ‘Calls on the Member States to take all necessary action to end discrimination against people living with HIV/AIDS, to promote and protect all human rights and fundamental freedoms, paying particular attention to all people vulnerable to and affected by HIV, to review laws and policies that adversely affect the delivery of effective HIV programmes and to ensure that people living with HIV/AIDS are involved and represented when anti-discrimination policies are drawn up; stresses the importance of taking account of the gender perspective in combating discrimination, so as to develop a comprehensive HIV/AIDS approach’

 
  
 		 

  Barbara Matera (PPE), in writing. – (IT) HIV infection is still a widespread phenomenon in our society and people are often unaware that they have been infected. Accordingly, we need to take all necessary measures in terms of treatment, but also in terms of prevention, since AIDS is a preventable disease. In this vein, I support HIV/AIDS prevention programmes becoming an integral part of sexual and reproductive health care and making it easier for women to have access to preventive treatment, since they often run into difficulties due to lack of available financial resources and their child care responsibilities. I therefore welcome the measures put forward by the rapporteurs both to the EU institutions – the Commission and the Council – and to the Member States, in order to improve and increase the effectiveness of the fight against HIV/AIDS in the European Union and neighbouring countries. That is why I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

 
  
 		 

  Mairead McGuinness (PPE), in writing. – This resolution marks an important step towards addressing the EU response to AIDS/HIV within Member States and neighbourhood countries. More than 2.2 million people are currently living with HIV in the EU. I support the general text of this resolution. However, I did not vote in favour of parts of paragraphs 10, 14, 22, and Recital AA, since these are, and should remain, matters of competence for national governments. I abstained in the final vote on the resolution as a whole because those points of Member State competence received majority support.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Combating AIDS requires a global response and a global commitment, in which preventive measures and strategies are the key to reducing the number of people infected. Information and high-quality services and products to protect against transmission and to promote safe behaviour are essential for the fight to be effective. It is regrettable, however, that advantage has been taken of this resolution to include issues relating to abortion and emergency contraception. I believe these issues are not part of the objective of this resolution and should be treated more responsibly, as they raise serious ethical questions. Since I voted against that paragraph, and as it was adopted by a majority of Members, I abstained from the final vote on the resolution.

 
  
 		 

  Willy Meyer (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (ES) AIDS is a disease that can be fully prevented. Primary prevention measures that provide the necessary information, technical skills, services and products to protect people from catching HIV and promote safer behaviour are the cornerstones in preventing the spread of this disease. It is fundamentally important that the Commission develops joint measures to ensure that human rights are fully respected and human rights-based approaches are followed in HIV/AIDS policies, including information campaigns to combat the stigmatisation of and discrimination against carriers. This resolution calls on the Member States to do everything necessary to put an end to any kind of discrimination against people infected with HIV/AIDS and to promote and protect all human rights and fundamental freedoms, with particular focus on vulnerable people and those infected with HIV. It also urges them to review laws and policies that hinder the running of effective HIV programmes and to ensure that people infected with HIV/AIDS participate in drafting anti-discrimination policies. That is why I voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Louis Michel (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) According to the report published by WHO and UNAIDS, 2.7 million people became infected with HIV in 2010 and 34 million people are living with HIV. HIV/AIDS prevention through effective information is still key. As the only means of effective prevention against HIV/AIDS, condoms should be made available free of charge or at an affordable price. Likewise, free and anonymous screening should be the main focus of a European prevention campaign. We should welcome the efforts made in sub-Saharan Africa, particularly in Rwanda, Namibia and Botswana, where there has been a 30% overall annual increase in the number of people receiving antiretroviral treatment.

The economic crisis must not slow down or hinder the use of new technologies and new approaches to improving the efficiency and effectiveness of HIV-prevention programmes.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – The report is very important because the Commission and Member States should ensure adequate funding and investment to carry out the research needed to implement effective HIV programmes that give equal and timely access to HIV testing, treatment and care to all, and calls on the Member States to direct their policies towards ending the discrimination and social exclusion often associated with people living with HIV/AIDS and to protect fundamental rights. I voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Claudio Morganti (EFD), in writing. – (IT) The problem resulting from the spread of the HIV virus is still a dreadful reality, some 30 years since its discovery. The resolution presented today definitely has positive aspects, such as the call to bolster the tools for detecting and preventing the virus, the need to improve assistance for affected people and the plea for investment in research so that this syndrome can finally be defeated. It also looks important to have a proper information and awareness campaign in order to combat the persistent prejudices in our society. However, I was unable to vote in favour since this resolution contains a message that is not acceptable for me. I am referring to Article 22, which suggests that abortion is a legitimate way to prevent infection. I therefore abstained because, although I support combating AIDS in general, I cannot allow any concessions in favour of abortion.

 
  
 		 

  Radvilė Morkūnaitė-Mikulėnienė (PPE), in writing. – (LT) It is symbolic that, at the same time, we are marking World AIDS Day and the twentieth anniversary of the death of perhaps the most famous person to have died from this disease, the singer Freddy Mercury. I welcome the European Parliament’s position and proposals for combating this disease more effectively, regarding information, prevention and the aspects relating to human rights. I nevertheless wish to draw attention to the fact that the resolution is quiet on one of the ways in which HIV is transmitted – through the use of intravenous drugs. In my country, Lithuania, more than 70% of HIV carriers have been infected in this very way. I am therefore convinced that if they wish to successfully combat the spread of HIV and AIDS, the Member States also have to take a comprehensive view of that in their anti-drug policies and strategies.

 
  
 		 

  Siiri Oviir (ALDE), in writing. – (ET) On today’s World AIDS Day, 30 years after the world found out about HIV and AIDS, it is still important to draw attention to this painful problem. The European Parliament resolution I supported reveals the sad statistic that today, 33.3 million people throughout the world have been infected with HIV, i.e. as much as the total population of Canada. The only cause for celebration is that society’s efforts in the struggle against HIV/AIDS have borne fruit, and a reduction of nearly 20% in the number of cases of new infections during the last decade has been achieved, and similarly, the number of AIDS-related deaths has fallen in recent years. Above all, I believe that it is important to emphasise a stronger focus on prevention because it is infinitely most costly to deal with consequences, and not only in financial terms. For that purpose, Member States should, above all, contribute more to scientific research into preventive technologies, while securing the broader involvement of researchers and representatives of civil society.

 
  
 		 

  Alfredo Pallone (PPE), in writing. – (IT) One of the biggest health problems in this day and age is undoubtedly HIV and AIDS. Even though information is now very widespread, statistics show that there is a new infection every three hours. That is why I think it is essential for the EU to continue its battle against this tragedy, which continues to affect millions of people around the world. We are talking not only about poor and underdeveloped areas, as some parts of Africa can be, but of the whole world, of Europe. I think persevering in order to reach a shared response is necessary and important, while we must remain diligent at all times.

 
  
 		 

  Georgios Papanikolaou (PPE), in writing. – (EL) I voted in favour of the joint resolution. The report of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control on HIV surveillance states that, in 2009, 25 917 new cases of HIV infection were reported in countries of the European Union and European Economic Area. However, the situation in Greece is far worse. The increase in the percentage of patients with the virus has hit the 1 250% mark within a year. The reason is deliberate action by drug users to catch the virus, so that they can claim social benefits, and uncontrolled prostitution. The necessary measures which the present report calls on the Member States and the Commission to take are the right measures, but are probably too little too late for Greece. That is why the New Democracy group filed a written question to the Commission today, asking for Community resources to combat the spiralling increase in cases in Greece.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted for this resolution, since I agree with most of the points it makes. I would, however, like to emphasise that stigmatisation and discrimination must be combated, as they make fighting the spread of HIV/AIDS considerably more difficult.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. –? (PT) It is estimated that there are currently 2.2 million people living with the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) in the European Union and neighbouring countries. It is known that the transmission of this disease is preventable and adequate prevention would clearly allow the rate of infection to be reduced to virtually zero. In addition, timely detection can considerably reduce the effects of infection on health. Statistical data have shown that the infection rate can be reduced by 96% in cases of early treatment. This context justifies a holistic approach to increase the information available to citizens at various levels, whether at the preventive level or at the next level of controlling the disease.

 
  
 		 

  Frédérique Ries (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) Today, World AIDS Day, it is important for the European Parliament to send out a clear and consistent message. Despite the extraordinary progress made to date in HIV prevention and screening, we must remain vigilant and continue to uphold the objective of a ‘zero spread’ of the epidemic. That is the message that the European Parliament is sending out today in adopting a resolution calling for fairer access to screening, treatment and care, so as to reduce the number of HIV infections. Every year, over 27 000 people are infected in Europe, including 1 196 in Belgium in 2010, in other words, more than three a day. Although the impact of antiretroviral drugs is extremely effective – far fewer people now die from AIDS – we cannot afford to be complacent regarding safe sex or trivialise the risks of contamination. HIV is extremely complex and still raises many issues, for instance, the issue of co-infection, in particular, with tuberculosis and viral hepatitis B and C. The European Parliament’s resolution is part of an ongoing effort, in anticipation of a long-awaited vaccine.

 
  
 		 

  Robert Rochefort (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) In 2009, over 160 000 people became infected with HIV in the European Union and neighbouring countries, bringing the number of people living with this virus to more than 2.2 million, according to the WHO. While the number of infections is increasing at an alarming rate, particularly in Eastern Europe, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control estimates that 30% of those infected are unaware of their condition. However, recent trials have shown that early access to treatment reduces both the infectiousness of patients and the HIV-transmission rate by up to 96%. Faced with this situation, I welcome the adoption of this resolution. Through this vote, we are calling, in particular, on Member States to promote and support research on new prevention technologies; on the Council to address the epidemic by developing country-specific HIV action plans; and on the Commission and Council to promote early diagnosis and care. The text also calls on Member States to take all necessary action to end discrimination against people living with HIV/AIDS. I believe that this is a very important point.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. The EP: 1. Calls on the Commission and Council to implement the Communication on ‘Combating HIV/AIDS in the European Union and neighbouring countries 2009-2013’ and its accompanying Action Plan by: - scaling up the implementation of prevention strategies which effectively target regional or local epidemiologic trends and needs, and working towards universal access to prevention, testing, counselling, treatment, care and support; - supporting an effective response to HIV/AIDS in priority regions, such as the worst affected EU Member States, the EU’s worst affected neighbouring countries and the Russian Federation and other CIS countries; - developing means to reach and support the population groups which are most at risk and most vulnerable to HIV/AIDS across Europe; 2. Recalls that the enemy is HIV, rather than HIV carriers.

 
  
 		 

  Tokia Saïfi (PPE), in writing. – (FR) In 2009, 161 000 people became infected with HIV in the European Union and neighbouring countries, bringing the number of people living with HIV to a total of more than 2.2 million, according to estimates by UNAIDS and the WHO. Moreover, the phenomenon is of particular concern in the countries of Eastern Europe, which have been affected far more. I supported this resolution in plenary, as it recalls the commitments made at the UN General Assembly High-Level Meeting on HIV/AIDS in 2011, in particular, the aims of ensuring treatment for 15 million HIV-positive people worldwide by 2015 and of reducing new HIV infections by 50% by 2015. This objective is achievable if we combine it with all the prevention and health care policies in Member States, and seek the support of all stakeholders: not just associations and NGOs, medical staff and pharmaceutical companies, but also trade unions and the various national ministries. This global epidemic can only be wiped out through the coordination of all parties involved.

 
  
 		 

  Bogusław Sonik (PPE), in writing. – (PL) I voted against the resolution on the EU global response to HIV/AIDS because this resolution does not only contain provisions on the priorities of health care and improving living conditions and the treatment of people infected with the virus, which I support. The resolution also addresses the issue of abortion on demand, which has the support of neither the Polish Government nor myself. I believe that a resolution on HIV should not address matters which do not pertain to the essence of the problem, such as legal abortion, because it might mislead the public.

 
  
 		 

  Charles Tannock (ECR), in writing. – Regarding the vote today on World AIDS day, I wish to explain why I voted against in several RCVs on the issue of the right to abortion, phrased as ‘reproductive rights’ or ‘sexual health matters’ which is something for reasons of conscience I personally oppose when used as a contraceptive; furthermore, I regard abortion law as a matter for each sovereign country to decide in their national parliaments and in many developing countries, abortion remains illegal. Nevertheless, I have always championed the right for sufferers from HIV/AIDS to receive proper treatment everywhere and, in particular, for the international community and the EU to mobilise medical aid to countries which have poor facilities for AIDS sufferers, and for the EU to help fund antiretroviral medication and needle exchange programmes for drug addicts in the developing world. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution overall.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) According to estimates by the United Nations and the World Health Organisation (WHO), there are about 2.2 million people living with the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and there has been an increase in the number of cases diagnosed and reported both at European Level (with an alarming increase in Eastern Europe) and globally. Another alarming statistic is that, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, about 30% of people infected do not know that they have the virus.

There needs to be a global and cross-disciplinary commitment to combat AIDS, in which prevention measures and strategies are the key to reducing the numbers infected. Information and quality services and products that protect against transmission and promote safer forms of behaviour are essential if this fight is to be effective.

Against this background, it is necessary for the Member States and each European region to have a strategy appropriate to its reality, focusing on universal access to prevention, testing, counselling and treatment, so avoiding the stigmatisation and discrimination suffered by people living with HIV. As the group from 15 to 24 years of age is increasingly vulnerable, it is necessary to focus public policies on this group.

 
  
 		 

  Marina Yannakoudakis (ECR), in writing. – I voted for the resolution as I believe that we must offer our commitment to combat HIV/AIDS, as thousands of people are being infected each year. In the UK, 100 000 people are living with HIV and there have been 20 000 deaths in my country since the epidemic began. However, I was disappointed that the issue of reproductive rights and abortion was included in the resolution. While I believe that women must have appropriate access to legal abortion in order to keep them safe, it plays a slight role in the fight against HIV/AIDS. In my constituency of London, Chelsea and Westminster Hospital has made appropriate interventions to reduce the rate of mother-to-child HIV transmission to just 1%. The inclusion of reproductive rights in the resolution unfortunately caused a number of my colleagues in the ECR and the Conservative Party to vote against it. We must face up to HIV which, while being preventable, has no vaccine and no cure. I regret that a number of colleagues opposed, abstained or did not have the courage to vote on this resolution.

 
  
 		 

  Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (FR) I voted for this report, which demonstrates the strong political will of the European Parliament, and indeed of the European Union and its Member States, to get involved in the fight against HIV/AIDS. Combating this epidemic and all STDs or co-infectious diseases calls for strong action from the public authorities. The European Parliament is sending out a powerful signal, including by having the sense to point out that this scourge will only be overcome through prevention and ‘sex education’, as well as through ‘strong linkages between sexual and reproductive health services’. Equally important is the will, expressed by the European Parliament, to combat the stigmatisation of people living with HIV/AIDS. Such discrimination can even lead to care being denied, which is totally unacceptable. For once, we can welcome the fact that over three quarters of MEPs are willing to commit to this cause. On the other hand, I regret to say that some MEPs, no doubt influenced by equally reactionary movements, still have a somewhat backward-looking attitude towards this issue. Fundamentalists are not always Muslims and are not always on the other side of the Mediterranean.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) According to the latest EU data, the number of (reported) new cases of HIV infection is continuously declining, dropping to a new low in 2011. However, the latest trends in many of the countries neighbouring the EU are alarming, showing that HIV is still a major threat to public health. The joint motion for a resolution calls on the Commission and Council to implement the ‘Communication on combating HIV/AIDS in the EU and neighbouring countries, 2009-2013’ and the associated action plan, and to implement country-specific HIV action plans in order to combat the risk of new infections in a coordinated and effective way.

 
  
  

Report: Ryszard Antoni Legutko (A7-0387/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I endorse this report and believe that the association between Ukraine and the EU will bring many improvements to the Ukraine in the areas of the justice of democratic principles.

 
  
 		 

  Sophie Auconie (PPE), in writing. – (FR) As I am convinced that the European Neighbourhood Policy helps strengthen democratic principles, the principle of good governance and stability among our closest neighbours, I voted in favour of the Legutko report. Under the European Neighbourhood Policy, the EU is linked to a number of countries, including Ukraine, through action plans. Association agreements are the first stage of their alignment. The European Parliament recommends that the negotiations be based, in particular, on the gradual introduction of a free trade area, respect for the rule of law, undermined by the Tymoshenko affair, and the preservation of Ukraine’s political independence.

 
  
 		 

  Adam Bielan (ECR), in writing. – (PL) The association agreement with Ukraine is a huge step towards closer relations with our eastern neighbours. Given the need to make constant improvements to security and economic development, cooperation with Kiev will benefit the entire Community.

While supporting Ukraine in the process of reforming certain areas of life, as provided for in the Treaty, I also expect the Ukrainian authorities to be committed to the full adaptation of political, legal and administrative conditions in order to allow the free participation of all citizens in the political process. I consider the development of civil society to be extremely important, since it is a key element in democratisation. By raising the social consciousness of citizens and increasing their participation in public life, we will stimulate the growth of a modern and friendly Ukrainian state. I therefore support the call for the immediate creation of an EU Information Office. I am glad that the negotiations on the association agreement are being concluded during the Polish Presidency, which has placed a firm emphasis on relations within the Eastern Partnership throughout its term. I endorse the resolution.

 
  
 		 

  Sebastian Valentin Bodu (PPE), in writing. – (RO) The EU has made human rights and democracy a core aspect of its European Neighbourhood Policy. The future association agreement with Ukraine, which involves an unprecedented level of integration between the EU and a third country, will serve as a model for the European Neighbourhood Policy as a whole. The current political situation in Ukraine, especially in the area of civil liberties and the rule of law, is clearly at odds with the spirit of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement under negotiation. The EU is deciding to offer Ukraine a clear European perspective, which is in the interest of both sides. However, Ukraine also needs to meet all the criteria, including democracy, fundamental rights and liberties and the rule of law. The EU strongly advocates a stable and democratic Ukraine which respects the principles of a social, inclusive market economy and of the rule of law, including an independent judiciary, as well as human rights and the protection of minorities. There are currently genuine concerns about press freedom, the freedom of civil society, the conduct of the elections and the rule of law in Ukraine. The sentencing on 11 October 2011 of Ukraine’s former prime minister to seven years in prison and the trials of other ministers have raised serious concerns in the EU and are widely seen as an act of revenge.

 
  
 		 

  Cristian Silviu Buşoi (ALDE), in writing. – (RO) As a result of its size, resources, population and geographical location, Ukraine is a key regional actor which exerts considerable influence on the security, stability and prosperity of the whole continent. This is why it should bear its share of political responsibility. Ukraine is committing itself to implement a huge part of the acquis communautaire. Indeed, the negotiations are among the most advanced in the eastern part of the continent and should serve as a real model for the European Neighbourhood Policy as a whole. Although there have been some concerns about press freedom, the freedom of civil society, the conduct of the elections and the rule of law, Ukraine has repeatedly confirmed its commitment to European integration and to its ambition to become a Member State. I think that an EU-Ukraine Association Agreement is a key instrument for achieving this objective. However, to ensure that this association agreement comes into effect as quickly as possible, Ukraine must implement the necessary reforms and promote democratic values, human rights and the rule of law.

 
  
 		 

  Maria Da Graça Carvalho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The EU strongly advocates a stable and democratic Ukraine that respects the principles of a social and inclusive market economy, the rule of law, including an independent judiciary, human rights and the protection of minorities, and which guarantees fundamental rights.
